name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Friday, 13 November 2020.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We now come to the order of business. The final draft agenda as set by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 157 of the Rules of Procedure was distributed at its meeting on Wednesday, 18 November 2020. I would like to inform the House that I have received several points of order and points of order and I will give the floor to colleagues in the chronological order in which the questions are received.

name: Sven SIMON
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you for the development of the past week.  It is of central importance for democracy in Europe that the plenary of the European Parliament should also remain open to face-to-face events. This does not mean that we should be careless. But this is the place where we should discuss the big and sometimes small questions of Europeans. We need to significantly improve our debate culture after the pandemic. In addition, action under the rule of law must also be fully guaranteed in the crisis. We expect this from the governments of the Member States and we must set an example in the European Parliament. All measures must serve to maintain Parliament's functioning and, before restrictions arise, all the more lenient means must be exhausted. The rule of law also includes respectforing competences. Mr President, you are a strong man under the Rules of Procedure. Neither decisions of the Conference of Presidents nor of the Bureau can justify deviations from the Rules of Procedure or the Statute. With this in mind, I hope that together we will emerge stronger from the situation, and I thank you very much.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Mr President, I would like to raise a point of order under Rule 39. In Hong Kong, four members of the Legislative Council have been disqualified from serving in their democratically elected positions by an order from Beijing, which violates Hong Kong’s Basic Law. As a consequence, the remaining 15 legislators from the democratic camp have also resigned.  The European Parliament, in keeping with our resolutions on Hong Kong, should raise these issues with the Chinese authorities. I call on you, Mr President, to take this up. I believe sanctions are needed to respond. Let me close by also highlighting the fate of the 12 Hong Kong youths that are languishing in detention in Shenzhen and must be returned to Hong Kong, and by expressing solidarity with the opposition trio of Joshua Wong, Agnes Chow and Ivan Lam, who are threatened with jail for organising a peaceful protest last year.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We now come to the agenda. I would like to inform you that, pursuant to Rule 163 of the Rules of Procedure, I have received two requests for urgent procedure, in order to add the following legislative documents for adoption during this part-session. The first concerns the General Export Authorisation of the Union for the export of certain dual-use products from the Union to the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The second concerns transitional provisions on value added tax for COVID-19 vaccines and in vitro medical diagnostic devices for this disease in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. These requests will be put to the vote today at the first voting time. Under the Rules of Procedure, only the authors of requests and one speaker against, as well as the chairmen or rapporteurs of the relevant committees, may be heard. Is there anyone in the Chamber who wishes to speak on one of the requests for urgent procedure? If there's no one, let's move on. With regard to two Council positions on: - Cooperation between the judicial authorities of the Member States in the field of the taking of evidence in civil and commercial matters, and - Notification and communication in the Member States of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters, I would like to inform the House that no proposals have been submitted to reject the Council's positions, nor have amendments been tabled pursuant to Articles 67 and 68 of the Regulation.  The proposed acts are therefore deemed to have been adopted. I would also remind you that this distribution may be subject to further changes. Information on the distribution of votes in different shifts is, however, available on the European Parliament's website in the "Priority Information and Documents" section. (The order of business was thus established)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by David Cormand, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on 'Towards a more sustainable single market for businesses and consumers' (2020/2021(INI) (A9-0209/2020)).

name: David CORMAND
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, dear David, good morning to all of you, we are going to debate today an important initiative report, since it concerns the issue of the sustainable market of the European Union. The European Union is the world's largest market, it is not nothing. And so as such, we have the power and the ability to prescribe a number of rules that not only preserve the planet, that also preserve sustainable jobs in our territories and that protect consumers. The purpose of the report I am going to present to you is to review a number of rules, to propose a reflection so that we can move forward. It is good that we are talking about it in Parliament because it is also on the Commission's agenda and we have already had the opportunity to talk to the IMCO committee with Commissioner Reynders. We can therefore, as parliamentarians of the European Union, begin to chart a course in relation to our ambitions. The context is also that of the Green Pact. But how can we think of an ecological transition if we don't review the rules of the market? Because ladies and gentlemen, in reality, our consumer society has become a consuming society, where resources are wasted and destroyed and where poor consumer products are often produced outside our borders, which make consumers and consumers, especially the most vulnerable, dependent on products they are often forced to replace. , which is not very good for their wallet either. So how is this report organized? First, the issue of premature obsolescence must be addressed. This issue is to ensure that consumer products have a shorter lifespan than would be expected of them and therefore we propose that this premature obsolescence be added to the blacklist of unfair business practices. We also want to extend the legal guarantee. As we know, manufacturers are able to produce, for example, washing machines that last ten years or more, and the legal guarantee is very reduced. Again, to protect consumers, we propose to extend this legal guarantee. We also want to add a usage meter, you know, like car mileage meters, on a number of consumer products, put in use meters that promote their second life, resell them, and enlighten consumers. For digital goods, we also want to separate the corrective updates that are needed from the scalable updates that all too often accelerate the obsolescence of digital products. We want a right to repair for objects that would allow for delays in accessing spare parts at an acceptable price. All the studies we have done at european union level show that more than three-quarters of European citizens want to repair their belongings more. This means that spare parts are not too expensive and that the time to obtain them is as short as possible. And we also want clear and harmonized information about product sustainability, which is absolutely fundamental. We are therefore in favour of mandatory posting, and that is the subject of an amendment that will be proposed to you. A mandatory display so that everyone can know the environmental quality of a product, because the latter has a known cost, it is the cost of purchase, but it also has a hidden cost, it is the cost that this product really costs at the environmental level. On the other hand, in relation to advertising, we want to frame the so-called green claims, which are misleading. There must also be some form of ethics in advertising so as not to mislead consumers. Finally, we want to promote sustainable products in public markets, which account for 16% of GDP in Europe. It is therefore essential to give a boost to sustainable products and quality objects, often made by European producers, to make them criteria for awarding public contracts and give them more importance and a prescriptive value. We also want to make product sustainability data public and transparent. We want there to be a digital passport of products that are put on the market so that everyone can know the environmental quality of these products, and that there is a sustainable digital index, because digital, which is often seen as something intangible, actually has very concrete consequences. There there is also a need for transparency and consumers need to be informed. Finally, we want to strengthen surveillance of the European market. It is not normal for objects that do not meet the standards we enact to enter our territories, especially through online purchases. This is unacceptable and it is unfair competition from European producers. So we need ways to check. These are my dear friends, the essence of this report. Once again, our ambition is both to protect European jobs, to protect the planet, with a more sustainable market, and above all to protect consumers so that they can be enlightened and not seen as cash cows in the economic model, as they still too often are today.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Thank you very much Mr Cormand, thank you very much to the rapporteur of Parliament. I now turn to Commissioner Reynders on behalf of the Commission. I thank him on behalf of President Sassoli and on my own behalf for his presence here today. Please, Commissioner.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: membre de la Commission. – Avec plaisir, Monsieur le Président, merci de me donner la parole. Je voudrais tout d’abord évidemment remercier le rapporteur, Monsieur David Cormand, et le féliciter pour son rapport pour un marché unique durable. La Commission européenne se félicite de l’initiative de la commission IMCO, ainsi que de l’engagement du Parlement européen pour le développement durable. Nous partageons l’ambition d’une action politique forte et multidimensionnelle au sein de l’Union, afin de faciliter davantage la transition vers une économie plus durable, plus efficace dans l’utilisation des ressources et plus circulaire. The Commission set its out strategy in the Circular Economy Action Plan adopted earlier this year. Like Mr Cormand’s report, the Circular Economy Action Plan recognises that the transition will require measures both on the supply and the demand side. We agree that a number of the changes needed, such as better rules for the lifespan and reparability of products, will require product-specific and sectoral approaches. Evidence shows that 80% of environmental impacts are determined at the design phase of a product, and that is exactly where the Sustainable Products Initiative will intervene. It will set out sustainability principles and specific requirements linked to environmental and social aspects. In this context, the digital product passport could combine unique product identification with data collected by different actors in the value chain. This could provide better information to economic operators, market surveillance authorities and the general public. It could enable more sustainable products, as well as the emergence of new sustainable business opportunities, strengthening the competitiveness of EU industry and the resilience of the EU economy. Various measures, both horizontal and product-specific, should also contribute to establishing an effective right to repair. We also want to ensure high environmental performance for all products placed on the EU market. Work is ongoing within the framework of the Ecodesign Directive, with the focus on durability, reparability and efficiency of products. This horizontal initiative, together with some sector-specific proposals, such as the Circular Electronics Initiative, will respond to a number of points included in your report. The New Consumer Agenda, which we will discuss later this evening, also provides for action on the demand side. It will include an ambitious programme of empowering consumers’ participation in the green transition. In 2021, a legislative initiative will aim to ensure better information for consumers. It will help them choose products, not only according to the price, but also based on reliable and clear information about the products’ durability, availability of spare parts and accessibility of repair services. The Commission will, at the same time, address certain commercial practices which undermine consumers’ trust – notably early obsolescence, as well as greenwashing. In parallel, the Commission will propose rules for the substantiation of green claims, to further reinforce the credibility of consumer information. Public procurement plays an important part as well as the demand side. The Commission is working on criteria and targets in sectoral legislation for minimum mandatory green public procurement, as well as comprehensive guidance on public investment into sustainable infrastructure projects. For green public procurement to be widely used, the environmental impact of products and services needs to be standardised and must use comparable assessment methodology. Several points in the report also touch upon the Sale of Goods Directive. This important directive will start to apply as of 1 January 2022. As announced in the New Consumer Agenda, the Commission will use the future review of the Directive to explore how it could contribute to sustainability goals, including by taking into account a number of issues raised in Mr Cormand’s report. Et je voudrais assurer encore, M. Cormand, que, comme je viens de l’évoquer, nous allons réagir à toute une série de points qui font l’objet des propositions qu’il a énumérées tout à l’heure. Nous verrons jusqu’où nous pourrons aller dans l’ensemble de ces remarques, mais je vous remercie à nouveau de votre attention. I am of course looking forward to hearing your remarks and possible questions and proposals.

name: Martin HOJSÍK
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Mr President, first let me thank my IMCO colleagues for this very important initiative. There is an overall agreement on the goal to become climate-neutral and a circular economy. The discussion is not about the goal, but how to get there and I think that is a very fundamentally good thing. It’s also symbolic that we’re having this discussion during the European Week for Waste Reduction, because let’s not forget that prevention is the best way to deal with the waste problem. Last year saw the heated discussion on whether premature obsolescence exists. I personally believe it does. They don’t make them like they used to, as the idiom goes. But it’s not only about the cheap products from China, it’s also about expensive goods and software from big Western multinational companies. A company with a popular fruit in its name and logo is a well-known example. Of course it would be so easy to blame the companies for all the problems, but it would not be correct. We all have a share. We all have a shared responsibility for the situation. We have created a system where the preferred choice is to throw away and buy new rather than fix or upgrade. So it is companies that need to change. It is the consumer culture that needs to change. But it’s up to us, the legislators, to change the system, to change it in a way that leads us to a climate-neutral and circular economy. This means more information and rights for consumers. This means stepping up our efforts against premature obsolescence by ensuring and supporting reparability of the product, reuse, replacability of the parts, extending the guarantees and changing the designs of products to extend their life cycles. This will not only help the consumers and increase their trust in the European market and the European ideas, but also create opportunities for small and local businesses across the EU, stimulate innovation and maintain the value of the product. I believe that this is the right step towards a win-win for citizens, businesses and the planet.

name: Arba KOKALARI
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The EU is the world's largest economy. We have 500 million consumers who make billions of purchasing decisions every day. Everything from what to eat to dinner to what to buy for car and which TV fits best in the living room. If we are to make these goods and services consumed across the EU more sustainable – well, it will have a major impact on climate emissions and how we consume resources. If we are to succeed in this, it must be as easy as possible for companies to change their business models so that they can start offering more of climate-smart, circular products and services in the internal market. If we are to achieve sustainable trade properly, we must dismantle barriers to trade. It must be easier and cheaper to obtain recycled materials. Today it is expensive. It's hard. Every country has different rules. And recycled materials are perceived as junk, instead of being perceived and regulated as materials that can be used again. We need to dismantle barriers to trade for sustainable services so that we can enable more repairs and rentals. Today, we have an incredible amount of barriers to trade in the EUROPEAN Union in the services sector in particular. This hinders the climate change change. We must remove the EU's own tariffs on climate-friendly products. We need to invest in new technologies and AI so that we can boost new and green innovation. We need to remove the jungle of labels that consumers see every day, so that it is easier for them to get clear information about what is more sustainable in a product and how products can be more climate friendly. Unfortunately, the Social Americans, the Green Party and the Left Party have completely the wrong focus. Instead of benefiting from trade and technology development, it wants to introduce bans, restrictions and new taxes that then prevent companies from making these important climate investments, where the goal is to stop consumption rather than create sustainable consumption. I do not think we should turn back the clock 100 years into a policy that leads to green planned economy. We have tested in Europe before and it did not work. I do not want higher unemployment or fewer climate changes. I will continue to oppose these harmful proposals and I will continue to push for a modern, green climate and environmental policy that actually makes a real difference and not just on paper.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: On behalf of club S&D. – Dear Chairman, since last term I have heard from citizens who notice that as soon as their product warranty expires, the device breaks down. They are convinced that these are built-in failures that force them to buy a new device. A recent study found that the devices actually last shorter today than those purchased by our mothers or grandmothers lasted. This is estimated to increase the financial burden per household member by as much as 110 euros per month. The industry's claims that consumers are buying new because they want, perhaps, a new design - it may stand for shoes, but they're certainly not buying a new freezer or stove because a new model has come out.  I call on all colleagues to support a firm ban on embedded blacklisting failures of the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive. This is something that our citizens want and nothing less than such a ban will lead to real changes in the market.  Each of us knows how frustrating it is when you want to fix a device for which you have set aside a good part of your home budget, but you can't because the spare part is too expensive or there isn't even one on the market. We used to be able to replace the battery on our phone very cheaply ourselves, and today it is dug deep into the device. We have reached the point that the cost of replacing the battery on the phone is unprofitable in relation to the price of the new device. As many as 80% of such failures can be easily solved at the design stage.  This report lays the groundwork for the introduction of repair rights, calls for better availability and reasonable prices for spare parts, as well as strengthening the repair sector and second-hand goods markets. Indeed, research has shown that reuse and re-use create more new jobs than throwing away or even recycling.  In order to truly change the buy-to-use-throw model underpinning our economy, it is essential to inform consumers! Our citizens have a right to know what they're spending their money on. Every time they make a purchase, they need to know what to expect from the product, which is why the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament are in favour of introducing mandatory device life expectancy labels as well as fixability. Studies have shown that consumers are even willing to pay more for a product that lasts longer and can be more easily repaired. Our job is to give them a choice. However, we must do everything in our power to make sure that a sustainable lifestyle is not just a privilege for the rich, but for everyone who cares about the environment.  As a result of the health crisis, the economic crisis is making us think outside the usual frameworks and work out how to create new jobs, save citizens' money, while achieving the ambitious goal of making Europe a climate-neutral continent by 2050. This report links all these objectives and I invite all colleagues to show during the vote that the New Green Deal is not an empty promise, but an opportunity for economic growth, environmental protection and consumer rights!

name: Sandro GOZI
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have made a choice to spearhead the ecological transition. We did it together and we saw our weaknesses and our blind spots. Today, we must prove that we are able to adapt and emerge as winners of the crisis. This is also true for the great European success of the single market.  Today, it is our duty to establish a circular economy with more sustainable production and consumption, to make our European industry more resilient and autonomous. To do this, it is imperative to review our entire ecosystem, including the single market. Every area must be studied, targeted, nothing should be forgotten. Several European countries have already begun to regulate in this area. I recall the French experience of 2018 with the anti-waste law carried by Brune Poirson. It is up to us, at European level, to affirm our ambition and to ensure that this fight becomes the norm in the European Union. Sustainable consumption must become our default choice. Today, we propose a strategy based on the principles of sustainability, consumer protection, competitiveness and fair competition. We call for establishing a right to repair products - because, as has been said, we are all consumers and we all want to see our rights strengthened - to combat programmed obsolescence practices, which are a reality, to better inform consumers, to guarantee an effective right of redress, to introduce sustainability criteria in public tenders and to reciprocid with third countries to make public markets more environmentally friendly and more Innovative. So far we have done a very difficult job and I want to thank Mr Cormand, all the other shadow rapporteurs and all the colleagues in the Internal Market Committee. A difficult job, of course, but a very constructive work. But in order to succeed, we must overcome our individualities in plenary and we must overcome our political divisions, because the greater our commitment and the more united we are in the European Parliament, the stronger our influence will be.  Every citizen must be able to enjoy real freedom of choice - but to be free, one must be informed - and appropriate and dignified protection. Let's develop this ambition and act. While there are risks and associated costs, they are much less than those of uncomfortable inaction. Change is the law of life and those who look only at the past or present are certain to miss the future. Dear Commissioner, with our proposals we call for the construction of a fairer, more innovative, more sustainable Europe, we hope that our voice will be heard and that, thanks to your proposals, we will together make Europe a pioneer in sustainable innovation and growth.

name: Virginie JORON
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, I would also like to thank Mr Cormand, rapporteur on this issue, for his excellent work and his listening. However, while we are voting on a report supported by the Greens to combat programmed obsolescence, to develop an ecosystem of repair and opportunity, these same Greens have thrown away, put in the trash, a beautiful nuclear power plant. The Fessenheim nuclear power plant, which is a few kilometres from here, not opened in the Middle Ages, but less than 50 years ago. The Greens got its head and it closed its last reactor in February 2020. What were they blaming him for? Its wear and tear? Argument rejected by the Nuclear Safety Authority which classifies it as the safest in Europe. They blame him for his old age. Cost of this fad: between 4 and 5 billion euros and more than 2,000 employees swung at the Job Centre. And everyone loses. EDF loses because the compensation paid to it is low if we consider that this plant could have run until 2041 and that it was equipment that was depreciated and in perfect working order. The state budget must pay 377 million euros to EDF, so the taxpayer loses. In the midst of a crisis, we would be better off using that money elsewhere. Our foreign trade is losing because we are importing coal and gas that we could have avoided burning in our power plants. The planet loses because we emit more CO2, all for purely political and ideological reasons. This absurd situation is not about to stop, since the Multi-Year Energy Act provides for the closure of 14 other nuclear reactors, when they are in working order and they would have been more useful because of the rise of renewable energies, because the more renewable there is, the more we need regular electricity production that is not dependent on weather conditions. To this stupid example, we can add another: the desire to close the European Parliament in Strasbourg, which is considered obsolete and expensive. Governing is planning and planning is designing things before others. We cannot say that this is the virtue of the Greens, but when we know that MEP Karima Delli, chair of the European Parliament's transport committee, confuses uranium and lithium with regard to electric batteries, nothing surprises us anymore. Ecology has always been in the DNA of the National Gathering. Also because our vision of ecology is pragmatic, humane, rooted, we support this report, because we are against the programmed obsolescence that pushes for overconsumption and nibbles a little more the purchasing power of our fellow citizens. Against food waste, against the disposable whole and for a circular economy with the repairability and recyclability of products within our territories. For example, the two-year legal warranty period is not suitable for all product categories with a higher estimated lifespan. The report suggests aligning legal warranty terms with the estimated lifespan of a property and ensuring a minimum period of disposal of spare parts. We are in favour of that. We are also in favour of sustainability and repairability labelling that takes into account multiple criteria throughout the product lifecycle. This labelling should provide consumers with the necessary and useful information at the time of purchase. When Apple restricts our phones, when smart printers block printing beyond a certain number of printed sheets, it is the consumer who is cheated. When Decathlon forges a fortune on the backs of Chinese or Bangladeshis paid 60 euros a month, the consumer must know. This enthusiasm of the Greens for repairability and sustainability must first be demonstrated here, I will repeat, by defending the maintenance of the Seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg and by stopping looking for spurious arguments to stop coming here in Alsace. Stop the double speeches, we must stop the work planned in Brussels of the Paul Henri Spaak building, worth 500 million euros and, in accordance with the European Treaty, return to work in Strasbourg.

Let us ensure that it becomes even the greenest, the most sustainable and innovative internal market in the world and, beyond the Brussels effect, even radiates beyond European borders. Every product sold here in Europe should be durable and not break down after two years. It should be repairable. This is how we delight consumers and we save resources.  The vast majority of consumers would much rather buy sustainable products, as countless studies show. With a mandatory label for the longevity of the products, one could make the choice of these consumers easier and made them actors of sustainability. Please vote in favour of our amendment! Many of the products are specially built in such a way that they break down after a short time. It drives profits when people have to keep buying new mobile phones or new kettles. We call for this planned obsolescence to be banned once and for all in the EU. We also have an amendment to this effect. The creation of the EU's internal market has been historic. Let us lay the foundations today for the creation of the largest sustainable internal market in the world!

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Cormand's report is a juxtaposition of several accurate observations with a great many wishful thinking and unrealistic demands.  Does the single market have its drawbacks? Of course. Competition between producers who compete primarily on price has an impact on the durability of certain products. But is this a reason to consider that shortening the life cycle of a product is a deliberate and widespread action, as the rapporteur suggests?  In the opinion of the ECR Group, this report does not provide evidence to support this thesis, and yet many new and costly administrative requirements for entrepreneurs are suggested. Any new bureaucratic burden hastily introduced, without proper market analysis and research, will significantly affect prices and reduce the competitiveness of European companies. At a time of economic crisis, this is a disastrous prospect. The centralist approach, according to which the unconscious consumer must be guided by the hand like a child, and each product should be basically identical, resembles a reality that in the countries of real socialism we remember all too well. I can tell Mr Cormand with a clear conscience that this economic model did not work then and will not work now.  Consumers make conscious choices, they themselves look for more permanent and environmentally friendly products, if that is what they want to buy. Entrepreneurs also want to be seen as more responsible and balanced. Whether they are credible or not in these efforts is also part of the market rivalry. We should not interfere too much with prohibitions and orders, which for many companies, especially small and medium-sized ones, will be another insurmountable barrier. I hope that the Commission will show more responsibility than the rapporteur and base its legislative proposals on reliable data. Instead of centralism and bureaucracy, we need pilot projects, advice, a system of incentives for entrepreneurs and reliable information for consumers.

name: Anne-Sophie PELLETIER
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Commissioner. We all live on the same and unique planet. Having responsible consumption to conserve limited resources should be consensual as we know that we need to change the way we produce and consume. I would like to thank David Cormand for his report, which, in the first hand, was very ambitious. Even as the Commission wants to address this issue, it is distressing to see how certain groups have done everything they can to empty this report of its substance. Finally, the doctrine of some colleagues is: yes, we must put green in the market, but without changing the market. Many European citizens have taken the measure of urgency and here in this Parliament we must be up to the task. We can no longer afford to sprinkle the green pact, because that would be fashionable. No, we must meet this challenge with consumers and with businesses by accompanying them and giving them perspectives through strong political signals. A sustainable single market is first and foremost common sense in allowing a mandatory label on products that indicate their environmental and social impact from conception to the end of their life. Second, it is to inform the consumer and bring transparency to the market and transparency is born trust. Allowing consumers to repair their product with spare parts available and at a reasonable cost is also common sense. If tomorrow repairing his washing machine costs more than buying a new one with the health crises we know consumers will go down that road. When we talk about purchasing power, let's talk about programmed obsolescence. A plague. I actually want to think about batteries that fall apart after updates or printers. Let's think about the consumers. Do you think, ladies and gentlemen, that if we defend this practice, we defend it properly? The big challenges we face are also to say that there should not be the market on one side and the consumer on the other. I want to remind you of this simple thing here: we are not asking producers to change the way they produce, we are asking for transparency on how they produce and an end to the most harmful practices for the environment. So it's not about opposing here, producers and consumers, they're the same. And all suffer from the race to the least social and least environmental that a market without limits wants to impose on us. In conclusion, I call on the Commission in its new strategy to first be vigilant about targeted advertising of the most vulnerable, responsible consumption is not frivolous consumption. Then, to look at the textile industry that pollutes with great strides and destroys its unsold, playing on the fashion effects of which we know the immediacy. I call on the Commission to be vigilant about the end of life of products and not to accept a near-systematic destruction of unsold goods, because as Lavoisier said, nothing is lost, nothing is created, everything is transformed. So let's try to stay as close as possible to this natural rule, for example by introducing a green rule that would not take more from the planet than it can restore in a year.

name: Dorien ROOKMAKER
text: – Mr President, as we have so many people on our planet, it is essential to adapt our ways of producing and consuming in order to tackle environmental issues. New technologies can enable this. Businesses should inform consumers correctly. Consumers have the means and are willing to share their views on consumer platforms. This is the new digital way of effective and efficient supervision. However, this proposal is an example of the old way of working. To bring legal guarantees into line with the estimated lifetimes of products is unwise. A legal guarantee is a kind of insurance. If the duration goes up, the price will go up. A guarantee does not stimulate consumers to be careful with their products. It will lead to more legal procedures and higher consumer prices. It will probably be beneficial for large corporations while diminishing the smaller ones. It will have a negative effect on innovation. It is the responsibility of national governments to think of ways to discourage over-consumption, and I hope they will.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for the work he has First of all, I believe that we are indeed all in agreement on this, and we do not want to discuss this for long. We want more sustainability in the European internal market, especially for consumer products, and we also know, of course, that we can promote this sustainability through political and legal measures. However, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we have opposed a whole series of proposals from the outset, because they contradict the market-based approach that we want to maintain in Europe – a democracy without a planned economy. We have opposed exemptions from intellectual property law, we have opposed the idea of introducing psychological obsolescence, and we have also spoken out against an EU advertising tax: we believe, rightly, because market principles – and the speakers before me have already mentioned it – help to ensure that the supplier who makes the best offer to the consumer wins in competition. , and it will be the most sustainable offer in the long term. However, I would like to raise two or three points which are important because they do not need to be reinvented in this parliamentary term. First of all, we need some legal certainty for manufacturers of consumer products. For more sustainability, we must also keep on board the manufacturers who need one thing above all else, namely legal certainty and the associated planning security. After all, we only renegotiated the directive on the sale of goods in the last parliamentary term , as the Commissioner will have noted in detail. And we have jointly agreed on a guarantee period that businesses and consumers must and must adhere to. Secondly, we need reliability in consumer information. Consumers must also be able to see the information attached to a product in order to make sustainable decisions. Unfortunately, the amount of product information that is already available to consumers today is often confusing. Now to print another mandatory consumer information on products, which ultimately only contains the presumed lifespan of a product, does not bring any added value to the consumer. Finally, we are talking about so-called premature obsolescence, i.e. German, the limited shelf life of technical products. Of course, it is not acceptable. However, the proposal to classify even an obsolescence that is not planned but premature is illegal does not bring any more than colleagues have already said before. Because there is no way to predict how long a product will last – it also depends very much on its use in the end. We therefore believe, Mr President, Commissioner, that the Commission should come forward with proposals for improvement in the interests of consumers, but please always with impact assessment and under the application of market economy aspects.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! A big thank you to Rapporteur Cormand for a very good report. Let me make it clear right away: we are not going to achieve the objective of the green transition simply by setting binding targets for CO2 reductions. We will only be at the end if we dare and have the courage to make a transformation of our entire society. And with this report, we come from the Committee on the Internal Market with very specific suggestions on how we can ensure a greener and a more sustainable internal market for the benefit of both consumers and businesses and our planet. The objective is clear: we need to change the way we produce and consume, otherwise we cannot protect our planet. We also need to ensure a way to have sustainable economic growth. This requires that we boost the circular economy, promote the recycling sector and ensure that the bill is not left with those who already have the least. In short: a sustainable green transition must go hand in hand with a just green transition, which is why I support our report. I think it's good. It launches a wide range of initiatives that not only enable consumers to participate in the green transition, but also ensure effective consumer protection along the way.  Let me highlight a few of the initiatives that I think are very important: a great many Europeans want to buy sustainably, but they do not have the information necessary for this, and that is why I think it is important that we should set up a labelling system that should clearly inform consumers about the life expectancy of a product. This makes it easier to buy more durable.  Secondly, consumers must also have the right to have easier access to have their products repaired. A large majority of EU citizens would rather have their products repaired than replace them. That is why it is positive that we are also proposing here, or that we are actually calling for a right to repair, that is, a right to repair its product. This should make it both attractive and cost-effective to opt for repair.  And thirdly, we must stop certain companies choosing to use planned obsolescence in their products. I think that products should be able to last as long as they possibly can, instead of someone wanting them to stop you before they are actually finished.  We need to change this, and that's why we need to ban planned obsolescence. We have a lot of initiatives in this report. I also know that Rome was not built in a day. We will not solve the climate problems in one day, but with this report we are giving a great deal of good ideas on how we can do this, how we can get on with securing a green and sustainable internal market.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, we all want to be more sustainable but this goal should not come at a cost to the European SMEs and the access of consumers to low-cost options and a wide choice of products. As for labelling, consumers are already overwhelmed by the information. Adding just another list of strange symbols or other marks to packaging that means nothing to the average consumer will not help. Instead we should focus on controlling the voluntary labels and the green-washing which often misleads consumers to think something is more sustainable than it is. The problem is not too little information, but misinformation. If we must work on better sustainable labelling, let’s work on making the existing Eco-design Directive better, not just adding another number from 1 to 10 to every label without any context. And let us remember that reparability doesn’t mean a better product. A product might be easy to repair, but if it breaks every week, how is that better than a non-repairable one that lasts forever? A poor quality product can be repairable. It might get a score of 10 for reparability but a D on energy consumption. This is misleading for consumers. Mr President, there must be a cost-benefit analysis and impact assessment for any proposed measures. If the costs are higher, while the environmental benefits are low, we should seek other solutions. Instead this report seeks to throw everything at the wall and see what sticks. It is a pathway to over—regulation. This is the path to further weighing down our companies with red tape, and a pathway to higher prices for our consumers. In the middle of a crisis, where millions are out of work, instead of lifting burdens we as a Union want to create more. I cannot understand this approach. Let’s be more sustainable, but let’s not destroy the single market in the attempt to be so.

name: Isabella TOVAGLIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a more sustainable Single European Market, with less consumption of resources, longer product life and greater protection for consumers, is certainly a merited and acceptable objective, but it must come to terms with reality. A harsh reality, in which the priority is to survive the economic and social catastrophe caused by the pandemic, in an increasingly competitive and globalised world. That is why we believe in a rational rather than ideological transition, progressive and with achievable objectives, facilitated by incentives rather than penalized by new burdens, but above all a transition compatible with the situation before us. The plastic tax, for example, risks blowing up entire sectors already on the verge of collapse: not only does this tax penalise businesses but it also does not protect the environment and consumers, since plastic requirements will still be met by goods from non-EU countries, which are the main producers of both greenhouse gases and plastics potentially dangerous to human health. There is a striking contradiction between the noble words and policies put in place by Europe: in words, Brussels wants to restart the economy and consumption, but it imposes production models that threaten companies and risk making workers pay the price of this transition; it claims to want to defend the retail trade, but at the same time pushes for the digital economy, without guaranteeing even-armed competition between the two worlds. Europe says that it supports local production and the right of consumers to transparent information, but then introduces misleading labels such as nutri-score, rather than legislating on traceability, thus penalising entire products without really protecting the health of citizens. It also encourages the short supply chain in public procurement, but does not offer entrepreneurs regulatory certainty about the environmental requirements needed to participate in tenders. Brussels is calling for more trade in the single market but then does not invest in strategic infrastructure, such as airports, and cuts funding to those who want to expand and upgrade cargo activities. Finally, Europe promotes low-impact mobility, but it should know that the electric car, and in general all the most environmentally friendly and durable products, are not within the reach of the majority of people, especially now that we are fighting for what is essential. Many fine abstract words about sustainability can be said in this House, but outside here there are nations in distress, where companies, workers and families are concerned about the more immediate future, even before the 2050 climate targets. If we really want to achieve a sustainable single market that respects citizens' rights, we must promote it with coherent and workable initiatives, confronting ourselves not with dogmas and utopias but with the dramatic reality we are experiencing today.

name: Kim VAN SPARRENTAK
text: – Mr President, in the fight against climate change and environmental degradation we need everyone, and therefore I welcome the initiatives announced by the Commission in the New Consumer Agenda on establishing the right to repair, limiting premature obsolescence and empowering the consumer for the green transition. But a truly sustainable single market should not only empower consumers, but also businesses for the green transition. We can support them by providing a regulatory framework that sets a clear direction towards climate neutrality, circularity and energy efficiency. A strong internal market shouldn’t be a place where the one best fooling consumers and externalising costs prevails. Clear rules will help create an investment climate where businesses that bring sustainable alternatives to the market are rewarded, instead of being confronted with competitors that are misleading consumers with false green claims or are bringing products to the market that break shortly past the warranty deadline. Consumers need to be given correct information on the lifetime and reparability of products. Voluntary commitments have been tried and have not delivered. Let’s take the next step and make this labelling mandatory. This will help to counter all the vague and false green claims that are thrown at consumers, and businesses with the intention of bringing durable and quality products to the markets will be grateful. Too many broken products with valuable raw materials inside of them end up in drawers. We need to be serious about tackling premature obsolescence. Providing evidence that a practice has the sole intent to shorten the lifetime of a product will be extremely difficult and will pave the way for producers to just come up with excuses. Let’s add premature obsolescence to the list of unfair trading practices. I call on you, all of you, my colleagues here today, to vote in favour of our amendments on mandatory labelling and planned obsolescence and not to water down the report, but to vote for a sustainable single market in line with our planetary boundaries.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Mr President, for a long time I have considered the overall benefit of the consumer to be a major objective both in protecting it and in creating rules on the market. The consumer's benefits include, of course, also the environmental impact.  This means that we should not take green measures without knowing their overall impact. Without data and analysis, it can easily happen to us that the effect will be quite the opposite. We should learn from cases of support for biomass or oilseed rape.  In the study for IMCO, experts say that the proposed mandatory extension of product lifespan can also have negatives and therefore recommend soft regulation, such as improving consumer awareness of the expected lifespan or reparability of products. I agree with that, too.  However, this report proposes what the experts in the study generally do not recommend, that is, harsh regulation. Since the measures recommended in this proposal are not supported by evidence and analyses, on the contrary, I cannot support this wording.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: - Dear Chairman, a European Commission survey has shown that consumers tend to fix products.  77% would rather repair than replace a defective product. Consumers who choose not to repair the product generally do so due to a lack of information on the durability and repairability of the product. It is obvious, then, that we need to work on better informing consumers. When purchasing, consumers must be informed of the product details, including, inter alia, information on the availability of replacement parts and product repair options.  Although a 2018 Survey by the European Commission states that 64% of consumers are repairing their products, the Eurobarometer on the environment provides different data. According to this survey, published in March this year, in the European Union only 32% of respondents said they were fixing the product. This is worrying data that shows a tendency to lose consumer interest in repairing products. This information obliges us to make additional efforts to establish the right to repair products and to guarantee to our consumers that they will be able to repair the product in a quick, efficient and affordable manner.  When it comes to consumer protection, in the context of a sustainable single market, attention should also be paid to the issue of early product obsolesction. In doing so, of course, deliberately designing and incorporating mechanisms into products in order to shorten their service life is unacceptable to us. However, what I would emphasize is that we do not need an ideological debate here, we do not need things based on individual extremist positions, but we should make decisions as Europarlamentaries, based on facts and concrete data and information. It is the special responsibility of all of us to conduct such a public debate.  I would also certainly point out that this should be taken into account, with all the measures we take to protect consumers, and the consequences that such measures will have for the single market. The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union clearly states that European Union policies ensure a high level of consumer protection.  It is therefore time to use achieving a sustainable single market as an opportunity to strengthen the rights of our consumers, in cooperation with entrepreneurs in the common market.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I once had a printer, which was only two and a half years old and did not draw in the paper anymore. I then looked and saw, a small plastic wheel had broken. I wanted to have it repaired, but it didn't work because the case was tightly welded, and even if it had gone up, I couldn't have repaired it because there was no spare part. We hear such stories in our thousands, again and again, from citizens. That is why we are saying quite clearly that this cannot continue; Sustainability is very different. Sustainability is such that you really have a right to repair, that you are not forced to throw away something that is otherwise actually good quality and buy something new. We want to protect the world's resources, we want to ensure that less waste is produced. Moreover , and this is also very distressing – we must finally stop many of the products that are bought, returned or not sold are simply destroyed in the major platforms. Why are they being destroyed? Because it is cheaper to destroy them than to send them back to the manufacturer. It cannot be either. We must ensure that information and good quality are brought back to the fore.

name: Svenja HAHN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU is faced with the task of converting the idea of the European Green Deal into concrete policy. The internal market, with its many small and large businesses and 450 million people, is the lever, because today we must shape policies for an ecologically and economically responsible future. But this report is not the way forward. This report breathes an incredible bureaucratic and protectionist spirit. It is simply unrealistic to make very tight rules and, at the same time, to want innovation not to be restricted, of course.  This does not fit together: progress needs freedom. I cannot therefore vote in favour of this report. It is a collection of over-regulation and far from a market-based approach and, as a consequence, would mean enormous costs for consumers and especially for small businesses.  The idea of man versus economy is fundamentally wrong. We are all an economy. We are all the internal market, and together we can take responsibility for a responsible future, responsibility for intact economic and environmental livelihoods for our and future generations. I want a single market that continues to provide prosperity, that gives all EU citizens opportunities that are a beacon beyond Europe – all that can be achieved through democracy and cooperation.  The way forward for this future is the social market economy. Instead of demonising economic growth, we should see how we can create new, more sustainable growth. For example, through circular economies: decoupling growth more and more from resource consumption. It is the market economy that creates new opportunities.  Let us therefore finally make full use of the potential of our internal market! Let us create a level playing field! Let us break down the hurdles of protectionism! Let us rely on the responsibility of the citizens! Let us rely on information and transparency and make consumer protection more European! And in particular: let us finally create a real digital union! Let us support research! Let us enable sustainability through innovation! The internal market is at the heart of the European Union. Instead of paralysing him with bureaucracy and prohibitions, let us finally unleash its full potential.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what can we say? What is needed at the moment for Italian consumers, for European consumers, it was even before the pandemic, before this emergency, it is even more so today. You need to be able to buy your own needs, your needs, and be able to buy them at zero kilometer, to be able to buy them at measured quality, that is, to be able to see what you buy. Unfortunately, however, The European policies and also the policies provided for in this measure, which Europe intends to pursue, look to the interests of the globalised world and not to the real interests and needs of the consumer, who would like to buy at the right cost but products from our territory. Today, too, this pandemic, on the other hand, unfortunately, leads our producers to great difficulties, leads our consumers into great difficulties and those who benefit from it are those who, on the one hand, are complicit in this pandemic – think of the Chinese, the Chinese products that are currently stealing other slices of the market – and, on the other hand, the large giants that do not pay taxes either in Europe or in Italy. So outside these buildings, even outside the Palace of Milan, people ask you: why does Europe not react? Why does Europe not find the formula for actually making these giants pay taxes, which today exploit the European market and the Italian market to the detriment of our producers? Why does Europe not protect us from selling products of the same quality in Europe and selling products in Italy? Think Cambodian rice, Moroccan oranges, Tunisian oil, products that come to our tables. Why did Europe, which was supposed to be the means of winning against other continents, now lead us into worse situations than when Italy was alone? The European continent had to win the challenge against America, it had to win the challenge against China, it had to win the challenge against Russia and the other giants. Today, however, Europe has led the Member States and Italy, producers and consumers, to kneel down to this continuous invasion of products of poor quality and at the highest cost to our taxpayers. Today, in order to be able to consume and to be able to consume, we must offer jobs in Italy and in Europe. We must increase our production, and to do this we need an instrument: a reduction in the tax burden. Europe cannot act in increasing the tax burden but must act in reducing it. One thing we said a few weeks ago and I repeat it: Europe renounces the VAT that it takes from the pockets of Italian citizens every day. That is EUR 2 billion. If that EUR 2 billion could remain in the pockets of Italian citizens to buy the Italian product, to buy the European product, we would be induced today. Taxing, for example, Chinese products that lead to unfair competition on our territory is another extremely important tool. I call on the Commission and call on Parliament to reflect on these proposals.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Among the many important issues for ensuring the functioning of a sustainable market, the issue of consumer safety seems to be the most crucial issue. Following a pandemic that has effectively disrupted the functioning of the market, mechanisms are needed to ensure that consumers buy safe and accessible products and services while supporting honest traders. Consumers, wherever they are in the European Union, should be able to effectively assert their rights vis-à-vis traders, just as traders are entitled to sell their products and offer their services to all consumers in the single market.  We need to think about changing the way we produce and consume in Europe. Products should be more sustainable, more environmentally friendly, longer-lasting and repairable. Undoubtedly, the main objective that we face is to find a solution to how to encourage sustainable consumption for consumers and producers to move towards a green economy. In this context, we need to consider whether imposing mandatory burdens and certificates on European companies, and thus passing on the inevitable additional costs to consumers, is the solution here. Actions to support and protect consumers must not lead to a narrowing of their choices. We must pay particular attention to this in order to maintain this important proportion.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: – A number of European reports and legislative work carried out in the Member States have highlighted the importance of addressing the longevity of products and the problem of accelerating product exchange. The aim of this report, which is being debated, is to be welcomed, but some of the rapporteur's proposals certainly need to be fine-tuned. I believe that the lifespan of products really depends on a combination of independent stakeholders: manufacturers, suppliers, distributors, consumers and even Member States. We must therefore not ignore the fact that prolonging the lifespan of products must contribute to the development of an economic model based on a balance between the needs of consumers and industry and environmental necessities. Consumers are dissatisfied not only because of the low durability of the goods, but also because they cannot be repaired. Indeed, many defective devices will not be repaired. However, support for the repair sector could instead create jobs, significantly reduce waste production and pollution, significantly improve consumer purchasing power and confer a commercial advantage on European businesses. That is why it is important that we act thoughtfully and deal with this important issue not only on the lines of irrational arguments, but also on the lines of realities, with sufficient weight. We are currently witnessing the fourth industrial revolution, which is being operated by digitalisation and an incomprehensible amount of data instead of a steam engine. While the first Industrial Revolution introduced the world to the phenomenon of waste, the current fourth has the chance to eliminate, or at least greatly reduce, the phenomenon of waste. The EU should therefore support circular business models, since what is waste from one industry may be the raw material of another industry. You may no longer be able to recover the wastes and by-products of a company in your own value chain chain, but with minimal changes, they can be taken up by companies in other industries. I am sure that by rethinking the production, sales and consumption methods to extend the lifespan of products, conditions can be created that could benefit the recovery of European market activities.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Before continuing with the debates, I shall proceed to the opening of voting time today. We shall proceed to the vote on the dossiers on the agenda. Voting time will be open from 6.30 p.m. to 7.45 p.m. The votes will take place in the same way as during the last part-session. For the appointment of Julia Laffranque to the Committee set up by Article 255 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and the appointment of Frank Elderson as a member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, the vote will take place by secret ballot.  Members will therefore be able to cast their votes in the usual way; however, the card they receive for signature will not indicate the vote cast but only their participation in the vote.  All other votes will be taken by roll call. Explanations of vote may be submitted in writing. Exceptionally, only explanations of vote of up to 400 words will be accepted. I therefore declare voting time open. I would remind colleagues that we will be able to vote until 7.45 p.m. today. The results of the votes will be announced tomorrow at 8.30 a.m.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the continuation of the debate on the report by David Cormand, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on 'Towards a more sustainable single market for businesses and consumers' (2020/2021(INI) (A9-0209/2020)).

name: Vlad-Marius BOTOŞ
text: – Mr President, we have all voted for the European Green Pact, we all want the healthiest, cleanest environment and we want to reach a zero-carbon economy as quickly as possible. That is why a clear strategy and rules are absolutely necessary to help us get there, to the green economy that we all want. In my view, innovation is the main factor that will help us achieve our targets much faster and better than the constraints on consumers, economic operators, public authorities. We need innovative products that are environmentally friendly from the first phase, from design to the last phase. For these we need collaboration with economic agents, with researchers, with investors, with consumers. From my point of view, we need to improve products, to innovat, to encourage and stimulate the purchase of state-of-the-art products, green products that pollute much less and can be recycled or reused in their entirety. Just as important is education, the dissemination of information, both in terms of the environmental emergency we are experiencing and in terms of how each of us can contribute to a cleaner planet. It is important that these two priorities – innovation and education – are united at the level of the European Single Market. It is important that the rules and standards for innovative green products and services are uniform, so that all European consumers can benefit from them, regardless of the country or region in which they are located. This report, in my view, is based on certain wrong pillars. We can talk about a second-rate product revolution, we can talk about the long-lasting product revolution, but it pollutes much more than ten new products, we can talk about an economy in which the State or the European Union decides the production and consumption patterns. But as we have seen in Romania, in my country, in so many years of communism and socialism with five-year plans, this attitude will only bring resistance to change. If we want the European Union and single market to be attractive to investors, we need to work with them, not try to put as many burdensome conditions as possible.

name: Robert ROOS
text: Mr President, this European Parliament excels at coming up with solutions to non-existent problems, only to justify its own right to exist. And this proposal is in line. All kinds of new regulations, obligations, quality marks for producers in the field of "sustainability". As a result, producers will face heavier administrative burdens which will of course be passed on to end-users. But contrary to popular belief here in Brussels, our consumers and businesses are very capable of contributing to a clean economy on their own. Thanks to information technology, consumers are better informed than ever, they are becoming more critical and considerations in the field of nature and the environment are increasingly part of purchasing behaviour. Smart producers respond to this.  For decades, the innovative capacity within our internal market has provided cleaner, better and more sustainable products, sometimes with a small regulatory push but that's all that it is. Let a facilitating role be the starting point of the policy. As the European Parliament, do not get behind the wheel on its own.  Above all, let us inform people to consume responsibly and to be economical on our earth and our resources. But leave the real solutions for a cleaner internal market to those who have already proven themselves to be very good at this: our engineers, our scientists and our entrepreneurs

name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a more efficient use of products and services is the way to ensure sustainable development. Resource management efficiency and the focus on the circular economy will help us to get closer to the carbon neutrality target. It is therefore imperative that a comprehensive and coherent strategy, a strategy based on scientific research, which increases durability, reuse and repair of products, should be developed. This is also an approach that will make it possible to defend the interests of consumers. However, it is important not to result in undesirable consequences, such as increased bureaucratic burden and the loss of jobs, growth and competitiveness of companies.  We must make this transition with companies and never on the sidelines. I also leave a call for attention to the need to maintain the levels of demand in public procurement, particularly in the criteria of sustainability and durability of products. I ask the European Commission for the courage, the political ambition, to implement these measures for the sake of our economy, our consumers and society.

name: Adriana MALDONADO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I like that we have a debate in this House this afternoon on an issue as important as the sustainability of the single market; an issue that certainly has to be current in a situation where the pandemic has shown that we need to change our consumption habits and ways of relating. Therefore, today it is essential where we produce and where and how we consume. Therefore, from an industry point of view, it is important that the European Union takes action on where we will produce and how we will be able to increase sustainability across the value chain, from design to product distribution. And, in relation to consumers, I think it is important that we give a tip, which is that in the last Eurobarometer, in a survey that has been carried out, more than 77% of Europeans are willing to reuse their products and try to fix them and usually do so. This fact has to make us think that European culture, European citizens are demanding a better way of consuming, more sustainable consumption. And, as the European Parliament, together with the different institutions, we need to be able to give an answer to these citizens. Therefore, from the Socialist Group, we believe that it is important to ban everything that has to do with the programmed obsolescence of products. It is important that consumers are not deceived. It is also important that there is a label informing you of the durability and how to resolve an error of any type of product. And finally, also — and I don't want to miss it – it is important that the public administration takes note, that public procurement is much more social and more sustainable.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, this report is committed to promoting a more sustainable single market for producers and consumers by pragmatically, consensually, realistically, but at the same time firmly and decisively implementing the principles of the Green Pact. Thus we lay the groundwork for sound and responsible economic and trade relations that are the first condition for transit to a circular economy. This proposal therefore gives a clear, firm and coherent message to the Commission, the Council, The States, industry, services and consumers. The transition from linear to circular begins in the same product design, in the possibility they offer to be reused and last over time. Continue with the guarantees we offer users to access accessible, quality and monopoly-free spare parts and repair processes, extend that philosophy to digital updates, and end premature or scheduled obsolescence. This bet obliges trade transparency and involves traceability. Both qualities should allow us to make visible the origin and durability expectations of a product, from the origin of the materials with which it has been manufactured to the possible destination of them at the end of its useful life. And this account must be based on product assurance, healthy and reliable business relationships and sustainable development. At the beginning of the twentieth century, when the world seemed to have no limits, in many cities of my country you could find shops called "the three bes": good, beautiful and cheap. This report is committed to fashioning all three erres: sturdy, repairable and reusable. Encouraging this way of doing is binding does not harm any manufacturer that based its success on honesty, innovation and quality.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Mr President, the pandemic we are all facing together has made us think about the future shape of our common European market. We must always bear in mind, above all, the interests of citizens as consumers and also the interests of small entrepreneurs, who make up up two thirds of jobs. I want to highlight three areas of this report that I consider important: digitalisation, public procurement and simplification. First area: Digitisation. In digital technologies, which also give us new opportunities for transparency, I welcome the initiative of the so-called 'digital product passport' to improve traceability and access to information on product production conditions, durability, composition, re-use or repair. However, I stress that, in these developments, account must be taken of the needs of the small firms that make up the most jobs. In the second area, in the area of public procurement, which accounts for up to 16% of European GDP, we should send out a clear signal for reliable sustainability criteria. I consider it most important to reduce the supply chain and to take into account the needs of small firms, which are often discriminated against in public procurement today, and we therefore need to improve their position. As far as simplification is concerned, I would like to stress its need, and I consider a common connector for electronic mobile devices to be such a typical example. It is important for the European Commission to implement our initiative and the European Parliament's decision on a common connector ending. This will contribute not only to simplifying facilities, but also to better recyclability and meeting environmental objectives.   However, we must always strike a balance in protecting the consumer and the sustainability of producers' abilities. Therefore, on the other hand, I would like to draw attention to the following: there is no need to tighten requirements in the area of spare parts. I believe that forcing companies to produce and store large quantities of spare parts, for which there is not necessarily demand, would not only damage the environment, but also the competitiveness of our companies in the Union. The second area I want to draw attention to is the services sector. This has a very important role to play for sustainability. We need to complete the internal market in services as soon as possible, because this can make a decisive contribution to a sustainable internal market that can benefit the consumer. Last but not least, I want to emphasise the area of standards. For digital technologies in particular, we need to introduce standards and protocols to improve interoperability and data sharing between firms, investors and institutions, which will undoubtedly bring further development opportunities. In this area, we also need to invest much more in research into new technologies within our budget. I believe that, in maintaining these principles, our common market will continue to be the engine of prosperity for our citizens.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Mr President, thank you Commissioner, thank you also to the rapporteur for the excellent work that has been done. Raising the sustainability of products, ending programmed obsolescence, is first of all an issue of consumer protection, surely, of protecting the environment and the climate, too, but also of protecting the production of our economy and employment. We must put an end to this reality, which is a form of deception towards consumers, which is at least how it is felt, to say the least. We must also put an end to all these products that end up in our garbage dumps and that clutter them every day. We must also act immediately on the products that are currently being marketed on European territory, I am thinking in particular of Chinese products. The Court of Auditors noted in one of its latest reports how Chinese products that were marketed in the European Union could represent a form of dangerousness - some reports refer to one in two products marketed in Europe. This issue of control of current products is obviously essential, and I am linking it to a vote that will take place tomorrow, I think, on product safety in this area, which is obviously an extremely important issue. I'm talking about that, why? Because yes, we will have to give our companies, especially the smallest and mediums, a little time to adapt and also produce mandatory labelling in this area in order to guarantee consumers all the necessary transparency. You have to give yourself a little bit of time, but the sooner you get started, the sooner you can help and support them. But I would also like to stress that we will now have to see, because this is lacking today, how we will control what enters our European territory so that these sustainability standards that will be raised are respected by everyone, and in particular by the largest workshop in the world today, China, whether in relation to bans , whether it is in relation to controls or the strengthening of them, even if the Member States are partly responsible for them, whether it is also because of what was mentioned by the President of the Commission, namely tariffs raised, taxation at our borders, carbon taxation or, in any case, non-respect for sustainability and products.

name: Sven SIMON
text: Mr President, thank you very much for the charming chair of the sitting. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I think that most of the speakers in this debate have shown that, of course, we want to make more sustainable products and the internal market sustainable in Europe. But what has also been said is also important: it is also about jobs, it is about consumers, it is about high costs and social compatibility. If, on the one hand, we create something that burdens people, then we must also ensure that we do not create bureaucratic hurdles, that is, a new bureaucratic monster on the part of the European Union, which will lead to widespread rejection in the Member States and ultimately harm the European Union. That is why we need to reduce red tape – for businesses, but also for consumers. I can think of an example, Commissioner Reynders, because you are here, an important example of the issue of cutting red tape: the so-called A1 certificate for workers in other EU countries. Many small companies, but above all scientists with me in Hesse, have complained very much about the fact that they are subjected to a disproportionate bureaucratic burden during short assembly work abroad, at two-day scientific meetings in France and Austria. I have therefore addressed the Commission, and the Commission's answer is: this is not our competence, it is the responsibility of the Member States, we do not see any need for action. But! There is. After all, there are many bureaucratic hurdles due to differences in the application of EU law. And I would like to draw your attention to this point: A1 certificate, please take it with you. There is a need for action here on the part of the Commission, which has the uniform application of Union law for the enforcement of the internal market within its sphere of competence. That would be an example where we can reduce bureaucracy, and then we can also create new requirements for businesses and consumers in the area of sustainability.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: – Dear Chairman, for years consumers have encountered anomalies that need to be corrected. We must strive to create a market where consumers can buy safe and affordable products and services without fear and make, above all, informed decisions.
