Consumers today are the focus of many controversies and need to be provided with the necessary protection. On the other hand, there is a need to find a way to enable producers operating in a responsible and sustainable manner to take advantage of the market, especially small and medium-sized enterprises that we need to relieve and not impose additional burdens on them. It is also important to mention the promotion and equalification of European standards that will ensure the durability and quality of all products. This is particularly true of today's global economy, in which we must protect businessmen. This would achieve a dual role for standards, through consumer protection, but also for the protection of businessmen.  It is necessary to promote the reuse of products and repairs, and to try to suppress, of course, as far as possible, practices that shorten the life of products available on the market. It is essential that consumers are provided with the so-called right to repair by making repairs more cost-effective and attractive. One way is to better access information about product repair and maintenance. In this context, I want to mention the establishment of a single charger - it was an important step forward towards reducing electronic waste and preserving the environment. In times to come, we must turn to more sustainable systems that will make the future easier for our citizens. The single market, in fact, has made Europe attractive for business and life. It must be used to its full potential, but also adapt, of course, to change.  But we need to find a balance between the economy and life. I think we're on the right track. We will never propose something perfect, but in any case we must find a good thing for the economy, but also for our citizens.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, thank you very much. Let me, first of all, thank all those who have spoken today in a debate to which I believe the various European institutions are very keen. In any case, I can say that, beyond the report discussed today, this is work that we will also be talking about in a few minutes, on the consumer agenda that the Commission has just adopted. You know, the Commission is committed to strong action to combat climate change and achieve ambitious environmental targets with a comprehensive approach. The Commission has also made clear commitments to integrate sustainability into the next multi-year financial framework. Once the budget negotiations are over, we will be able to mobilise European funding to support sustainable initiatives. We need to organize and support the change in the behaviour of businesses and consumers alike. For businesses, as you know, the initiative, which the Commission will present next year on sustainable governance, will play an important role, but we will also do everything possible to give consumers a better ability to choose sustainable products, including, as your report indicates, credible and readable information on sustainability, a right to reparation, action in the face of programmed obsolescence or the introduction of programmed obsolescence. , to cite a few examples, sustainability criteria in public procurement. We will do this to strengthen the internal market and support employment, taking into account, of course, the particular issues affecting small and medium-sized enterprises. Administrative burdens should not be increased. We will also do this by developing actions to ensure product safety, including from third countries. We have begun the development of an action plan with China to strengthen the safety of products sold online, this is a process that will continue. So I thank you again for the attention you have given for a long time to this consumer protection, I would say above all to strengthening rights and implementing consumer rights. I look forward to continuing our collaboration towards a more sustainable European internal market. As you know, consumer protection is one of the most visible areas for European citizens, since it is now more than 50 years since the European Union began this policy in favour of consumer protection and rights.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place on Tuesday, 24 November 2020 and the final vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 November 2020. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Writing. – The transition to a sustainable and sustainable economy is undoubtedly important. A sustainable single market strategy must be fair and balanced and provide our businesses with competitive advantages in a global context. Unfortunately, this report does not present liberal and market-based solutions for sustainability, but contains new binding and mandatory requirements that go too far and lead to over-regulation. I am not in favour of putting a greater administrative and financial burden on our producers and businesses during the crisis. In many respects of this report, we must ask the question - what is the problem that we are solving?

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: Writing. – It is regrettable that even today we do not guarantee our consumers in the European Union a real opportunity to have the goods purchased repaired at an affordable price even after the warranty period has expired. At the same time, almost 80% of EU consumers would prefer to repair a broken appliance rather than buying a new product, but due to the excessively high price of repairs or even the absence of spare parts, our citizens often have no choice but to buy a new product. The lifespan of many household appliances on the European market is significantly lower than it was a few years ago, as demonstrated by European surveys, and the existence of so-called spoilers can no longer be described as hoaxes. While refrigerators once lasted 20-30 years, today many terminate the service shortly after the warranty period expires. That is why I am strongly in favour of banning the use of procedures that deliberately shorten the lifespan of products, known by the familial name of a spoiler, which is also the subject of our amendment. This is despite the fact that a large proportion of fellow MEPs from the right-wing spectrum are opposed to this effort. We need to introduce legislatively the right to affordable repair by a professional service, as well as a guarantee for spare parts valid throughout the Union. We must also insist on the introduction of one universal mobile phone charger, which would significantly reduce the production of electronic waste.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on 'Towards a new consumer agenda beyond 2020' (2020/2874(RSP)). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted. In addition, there are interventions at a distance from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States for members.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me begin by thanking you again for this invitation to present to you, this time, the new consumer agenda published by the Commission on 13 November. This agenda echoes many of the Suggestions of the European Parliament, whether in reports or in other debates in Parliament. For example, on issues such as the sustainability of the internal market, which we have just talked about, or product safety, which will also be on your agenda this week. I think it is important that we can continue to work together on these issues. Europe is known for its high level of consumer protection. With the New Agenda, we want to uphold this European achievement. The Agenda will allow us to ensure that European consumers benefit from the single market, also in a crisis period like the current pandemic. The Agenda sets out a political vision and longer-term priorities, aiming to build trust so that consumers can be key actors for the green and digital transitions and also be key to drive the economic recovery out of the COVID-19 crisis. The Agenda proposes 22 concrete actions. This to address both the immediate challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as longer-term priorities. Our long-term priorities include consumer protection in green and digital transitions. The approach set out in the new agenda will contribute to the implementation of the circular economy and digital strategy action plan, including through more sustainable and safer products and services. The new agenda calls for action to better inform products' environmental characteristics, such as their lifespan, environmental impact and repairability. We will better protect consumers from practices such as eco-money laundering, early obsolescence or the sale of unsustainable products. We will also ensure that the needs of a strong legal framework on artificial intelligence can be met to ensure a high level of consumer protection and fundamental rights online. Consumers need to be able to shop online safely and confidently, as well as in the physical world. The digital transition also has an impact on the consumer credit market. These include new lenders and new ways to assess consumer credit by using their online data. In addition to environmental and digital transitions, the new consumer agenda addresses three other priorities: effective enforcement of legislation and effective remedies, consumer awareness taking into account the specific needs of different groups and strengthening international cooperation. We must ensure that European citizens can enforce their rights as consumers, regardless of their social or economic situation. Consumer accountability in the green and digital transition must be inclusive. A high level of consumer protection cannot be a privilege accessible only to some, for example, those who have access to online tools and digital skills. Let me conclude with a few words on how we want to implement this new policy vision. Given the nature and global dimension of the challenges we aim to address, the agenda seeks to foster consumer policy priorities that could be pursued by the EU and its Member States.  The agenda also suggests a broad partnership, including consumer organisations, but also businesses and all stakeholders, including the European Parliament.  Thank you again for your attention tonight about consumer rights and consumer protection and I'm now looking forward to hearing your remarks and possible questions or proposals.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: au nom du groupe PPE. – Monsieur le Président, Monsieur le Commissaire, merci beaucoup pour votre discours et pour la clarté avec laquelle vous avez donné les arguments en faveur d’une forte protection des consommateurs au niveau européen. I’d like to add, Commissioner, that the level of protection of consumers in Europe is high, and we should not say something else, lest we create misunderstandings. The level of protection is very high, but that doesn’t mean that consumers such as ourselves haven’t had experiences where the protection was not right. Therefore, the EPP Group wants to work on adapting consumer protection in those areas where it is not yet right.  Let me conclude, first, that it’s very often not the right level of protection in areas where we don’t have full harmonisation, so your task, from our point of view, is first and foremost to fight for full harmonisation, so that we can offer European consumers – wherever they live, wherever they buy, whatever they want to do – the unique and common protection that they merit. Unfortunately, here, we face a lot of resistance, and I kindly remind you that we believe that the best tool and the best project where we have successfully implemented this is the Passenger Rights Directive, where every flight passenger in arrivals at the airport can see their rights and can implement them. Therefore, it has taken us by surprise and by deception, that it was not possible in this crisis to offer all citizens that were flying in the Corona crisis in the first half of the year the same level of reimbursement. Some have been given a voucher, others have been given their money back – and this, in the European Union, in the 21st century is not what consumers merit. We discussed that when we were meeting in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. That is one important element. We need full harmonisation in consumer protection to make sure that we can move on to the 21st century all together in Europe. The second point I want to point out as well, Commissioner: we believe that consumer protection can be improved in some points, but we don’t believe that the new concept of vulnerable consumers is a valid concept, because there is no general definition of vulnerability. You can become a consumer in vulnerability if you break your leg, but if you haven’t, you are not vulnerable, so we have to adapt this concept with a lot of calm and prudence so as not to create further bureaucracy. One element where we have, in the past, had quite a difficult path with Parliament was the Consumer Credit Directive. If there is something to improve, the EPP is open and ready to work on it, but please, let’s make sure, Commissioner, that we don’t add further bureaucracy to a directive which is already quite difficult to apply in the interests of consumers, because sometimes they would more easily be getting a credit and that is something that we should not block.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: for the S&D Group. Mr President! A big thank you to Commissioner Reynders for a good presentation. But let me start by rewinding the time more than 14 years. At that time I was a newly elected Member of the European Parliament. Amazon was only in its infancy, and Facebook had only just been created. When we talked about consumer policy, it was about physical products and how we made them safer. But since then, a lot has happened. Today, online marketplaces outperform traditional physical stores. More and more of our production is taken over by robots and other technologies. On top of that, the green transition today dominates much of the consumer debate. The development has been strong, which is why it is also time for us to develop and adapt our consumer rights from yesterday's world to the world of tomorrow. That is why I am also extremely pleased that the Commission is presenting a proposal for a new consumer agenda. A proposal that not only calls for updating, but also for closing the gaps in our consumer protection rules. I am very pleased with what has been presented and I really think it is worth praising. This is one of the most ambitious things I have seen in the many years i have been a Member of the European Parliament, but of course there are also thistles. There are also things that can be done better, and I will touch on that in a moment. However, let me start by mentioning two things that I think are very good: I am pleased that the Commission is proposing to improve consumer safety on digital platforms. It seems to me that there is no doubt that what is illegal offline must also be illegal online. I hope we will see this not only as a principle, but also concretely translated into legislation. Secondly, I think it is very good that the European Union wants to make consumers more active in the green transition, but we have just debated that and that is why I will not go into it any more. As I said, the trees don't grow into the sky. In some places we should go further than what the Commission is proposing. I do not think, for example, that it is enough for information to be left alone. It must be accompanied by clear rules and clear rights for consumers. Take, for example, the idea of the green consumption pledge! Yes, it is important that we consumers know about the carbon footprint of companies when we pull goods off the shelves, but it cannot stand alone. We must also have a right for consumers, a right to have their products repaired. And then, moreover, we must also look at how we can ensure that market surveillance is improved. Perhaps there is a need to have a check on the checks that are taking place. I also think that it is really important to emphasise that, for example, Members of the European Parliament can also become much more clearly involved in the whole of consumer policy.  The trend has been strong in the last 14 years and will only be faster in the future. That is why we must also be efficient and flexible in our legislation, so that we can ensure green and digital achievements with consumers at the centre and not at their expense. So it is not about making more legislation for the sake of legislation, but it is about ensuring clear climate targets and a level playing field for the benefit of both businesses and consumers through legislation. I very much look forward to working with the Commission and with the European Parliament on this. Then I am sure that we will be able to have new rules which benefit consumers and which, at the same time, also benefit the internal market.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, my group welcomes the New Consumer Agenda and the many proposals and revisions foreseen in it. As I have little time, let me focus on four of them.  First, package travel. I encourage the Commission to look to the Danish example of their answer to the crisis, where the Guarantee Fund ensured that consumers were reimbursed within the normal delay, while giving a lifeline to travel companies to continue to have liquid assets and not go under. Such temporary guarantee loans seemed to work well for both consumers and businesses alike. But, whatever the final decision is, we cannot have the situation of the last six months, where consumers were used as free bank loans by travel companies. This is not acceptable.  Second, on general product safety and product liability, the key here is a tweaking of the law, not a compete redrafting of it. Much of the legal framework is still working and is working well. We cannot let fear of the future and technological developments lead to new rules that stop or slow down innovation. Risk is not in itself negative. All actions involve risk. If we had banned all products with an element of risk in the past, we would not have elevators in buildings, planes in the air or cars on the road. All innovations include some risk, which we should be willing to take.  Third, on geo—blocking, the deadline for the first review expired on 23 March, and here we are in November. I hope the delay will have given you time to draft the amendment to include copyrighted goods and services, like e-books, videos and music, within its scope. Our citizens should be allowed to buy digital goods across borders. It is time to say ‘enough is enough’ to national fragmented markets. Lastly, we still have the problem of dual product quality in Europe. This must be addressed and included in the guidance from the Commission on unfair commercial practices. We should go further to end this practice once and for all in the single market. So, Commissioner, we have put a lot on your plate. You can count on the support of my group. We just have to make sure that the proposals are balanced and the single market is not fragmented, but better completed.

name: Jean-Lin LACAPELLE
text: On behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, the European Commission published, on 13 November, its new consumer agenda, a strategy for recovery and post-crisis. It is full of good intentions, but you will allow me to welcome it with scepticism, because I had seen the same good intentions in the industrial strategy of the European Union, before discovering that in fact nothing had changed on the merits. It contains two main axes, one ecological, the other digital. I will focus on the digital part for which the European Commission intends to update its legislation. Its stated aims are clear: to combat the collection and use of behavioural data, to combat manipulation (false advertisements, tampered opinions, profiled advertisements), to strengthen surveillance of online commerce to identify defective products, to improve the marking and traceability of products and finally to regulate the digital transition of financial services and thus prevent citizens from being won over by debt. All of these objectives can only be agreed with, but they pose a dual fundamental problem. The first is that the principle of globalization is contradictory to these virtuous goals. The European Commission in its text admits that production and value chains are increasingly globalised and interconnected, but does not intend to change that. Take, for example, China, which is responsible for more than 60% of the defective products that enter the domestic market today. Globalization encourages free trade with China. What will prevent China from supplying substandard products or even cheap counterfeits to the European public on its own online trading sites? These are Chinese sites governed by Chinese law. What European legislation can make a difference to this? The solution advocated by the European Commission, namely the development of pseudo action plans with third countries including China, is a market of dupes. We have already tried this with the United States on the protection of personal data and we have allowed that country to plunder it by pretending to look elsewhere. Only the regulation and questioning of ultra-globalism can provide a lasting solution by, for example, putting in place customs barriers, which I note are totally absent from the project. The second problem is that our regulations will restrict the development of European technology. I take the example of artificial intelligence: by processing and analyzing data en masse, it can, for example, predict reactions in the event of a crisis, typically the health crisis we are currently experiencing. By prohibiting us from exploiting this kind of data, we will deprive our companies of valuable advances in this area. Our international competitors do not have these qualms, they will develop these technologies on their own population and then apply them in other areas, including offensive ones, specifying for example the most effective way to cause mass panic by attacking the organization of certain networks in a country. We will not have the means to respond. The only solution is to offer our data only to strictly regulated European companies and close it to third-party companies. This implies protectionism that is assumed to break with the idea of equal access to the public, the European Commission, of course, is not considering this solution. However, it will have to be considered. These fundamental problems will arise sooner or later and will demand solutions. So, ladies and gentlemen, I have said this many times and I repeat, it is the political will that we lack to actually carry out the necessary reforms, I urge you all to follow me on this reflection and on this path.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, passenger rights, product safety and collective redress – the EU consumer protection standards are amongst the highest in the world. And we can be proud of that. Yet the old EU consumer strategy is eight years old and an update is highly needed. What is at stake? The climate crisis is more urgent than ever and to empower consumers to make the most sustainable choices is something that we have to urgently do. With a proper right to repair and mandatory labelling we can make the consumers become agents of sustainable change. Many people fear that the digital transformation is going on faster than we, the policy-makers, are able to regulate. This cannot be. Consumer protection may not lag behind in the online world. I am very happy that the Commission took up in its strategy the concept of vulnerable consumers. There are groups that need a closer look, that might need special protection, like for example, heavily indebted fellow citizens. And we have to make sure that our high consumer protection standards are not undermined in trade agreements. Take the precautionary principle: it is a fundamental standard in EU policy-making, yet it is not fully anchored in our bilateral trade agreements, like CETA, and this needs to change. Commissioner, I am expecting ambitious proposals in those areas and am looking forward to working with you and my colleagues in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) on ambitious legislation. Trust of EU citizens in EU consumer protection is high. Let’s not disappoint them and let’s live up to their expectations.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The COVID-19 pandemic has irreversibly moved part of trade, both services and goods, into the digital area. In addition to the many advantages, i.e. greater competition between traders, faster purchasing and access to an enlarged supplier base for consumers, this change poses some risks. This is particularly important in the context of online platforms or sellers outside the common market who are not interested in complying with european Union standards. Such practices, on the one hand, put consumers at risk and, on the other hand, they hit European small and medium-sized enterprises.  In the face of economic collapse, it is essential to develop standards that support consumer rights without undermining consumer purchasing power. The Commission is facing the challenge of updating the rules in response to the challenges of a pandemic and at the same time not overregulate the regenerating market.  The revision of the General Product Safety Directive will be one such task. The legal framework developed for disruptive technologies – such as artificial intelligence – can make it the driving force behind the European economy and a tool to support consumers, or make European economies in the tail end of innovative solutions in a dozen years' time. The choice is ours. If we make good use of our predispositions and focus on innovation, the current crisis could be an opportunity for a development leap for Europe.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Madam President, the European Commission recently presented a new consumer programme. According to the European Commission, this programme strengthens the position of European consumers and enables them to play an active role in the green and digital transformation.  Before I get to the more positive points of this programme, I would like to express my regret that this programme does not mark a watermeal down in the fight against dual quality. It does not change the fact that the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive, which was supposed to definitively prohibit the dual quality of not only food but also other goods, is unusable due to the intransigence of some Member States of the European Union, particularly Germany and Austria, and the intervention of the European Commission for supervisory authorities in a number of Member States and effectively leads to its legalisation. You, Commissioner Reynders, said: 'European consumers are at the centre of global change. They can affect a lot of things by their actions. Consumers must be able to make sustainable decisions and ensure that their rights are protected in all circumstances.' And I ask you here, Commissioner: does this also apply to the dual quality of food? If the European Commission wants to defend the rights of all consumers, how can it accept the fact that different approaches to the quality of products sold are applied within the single trade area?  So is it now that if consumers say that they do not want double quality, it will be added to the list of unfair commercial practices as we demand it? Or rather, the European Commission advises consumers to go to other countries to buy their goods, which would mean, for example, for Czechs to take German trades by storm during the pandemic. Is that your goal? To be clear, I very much appreciate what the new consumer programme contains. I believe that in many ways this is a step in the right direction and, for example, the priority of effective enforcement of consumer rights is very crucial for me. I just have a problem with the fact that the European Commission cannot be consistent in its actions and often applies a half-hearted approach, and I am very sorry, especially in the case of consumer protection, and I consider this to be a fundamental mistake. Yes, let us strengthen consumer rights, involve more consumer organisations, combat premature product obsolescence, online unfair practices, but let us also not forget that, dear Commission, we have a huge debt to the citizens of the European Union from Central and Eastern Europe. You have not prevented double quality and I, Commissioner, please, will really start doing something. This is something that worries consumers in our country.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Madam President, I welcome the fact that the European Commission has come up with this agenda because we need to develop a European topic of consumer protection, and it is also an economic topic, because consumer spending accounts for up to 54% of European GDP in our Union. Consumer protection is taking on new dimensions in the conditions of the digital economy. It's no longer just about exchanging defective goods, poor quality service or refunding money. We are increasingly confronted with sophisticated fraud on the Internet, identity theft or a new phenomenon of so-called cryptocurrencies. These phenomena can no longer be dealt with by individual states on their own.  Any reform of European consumer protection policy must count on them. And we need to create effective mechanisms to protect our citizens from them. This topic is also closely linked to the development of AI technologies – here we must always bear in mind that the ultimate decision-making is man here. Not only in the process of using products and services with AI elements, but also in the overall AI-enabled end chain. A particular topic that I want to draw attention to and which deserves more attention is the topic of protecting children in the online space. They are particularly exposed to deceptive or aggressive business practices and often even harassment. I consider that a number of measures need to be taken to protect children, such as: firstly, to promote media literacy, to develop critical thinking and to develop the skills needed for analysis, which is necessary to recognise the difference between objective facts and subjective opinions. Secondly, initiate the establishment of effective age verification systems and ensure their use in order to ensure that children are protected from digital product, services and content and commercial exploitation. Thirdly, to establish an online mechanism for reporting illegal and inappropriate content on the Internet, including a rapid intervention system, and to prevent access to web content. At the same time, internet service providers, including social networks, need to be involved in playing an active role in preventing and removing illegal content. I think we need the Union principles for safer social networks and the extension of the use of the standard privacy settings for children who register on social networks in order to increase the safety of minors. We also need an EU-wide code of conduct on the sale of video games to minors. I believe that with these measures we will help to better protect children throughout the online space and contribute to a safer life for all of us.

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the time has come when we thought the Internet would make the market transparent by eliminating information asymmetries. We know that the opposite has happened, the market power of large platforms is enormous and grows every minute due to the network effect. It's more or less like going naked to the market. When we enter an online store, sellers know us better than ourselves and can therefore exploit our weaknesses and vulnerabilities. If we're looking for sneakers, they recommend us a gym, a personal trainer and maybe even a diet program. We thus need to "dress" to regain some power and privacy. Consumer data should not be used for purposes other than those for which it was provided, nor should data be collected that is not essential to provide the sought-after service. Commissioner, the digital transition has not just transformed ways of selling and buying. It has also transformed products, which are now confused with services, becoming intelligent and dynamic throughout their life cycle. From the car, which walks by itself, to a simple cooking machine, to which I order the king cake for Christmas, instead of going to the pastry shop, as usual. We need to prevent these digital products from becoming obsolete faster and, above all, to ensure that the speed of entry of new products into the market we are watching, European or imported, and their successive updates are not made by trampling our security. The revision of the General Product Safety Directive should therefore take into account the findings of the IMCO report, which will be presented today, and in particular consider the precautionary principle in relation to innovative products at greatest risk, making the burden of proof that they are not dangerous, and not the other way around. The slowest innovation, in some cases, may be the one that deserves the most confidence and the one that lasts without setbacks. Or the use of blockchain to ensure better traceability of products, or artificial intelligence, to strengthen the capacity of surveillance authorities. Commissioner, the new agenda, in these and other areas, should serve to give consumers the same weapons available to platforms and other service providers. In a moment, the new agenda should be a kind of software update of the current legislation, that leaves it without bugs, that makes it smart and suitable for effective consumer protection, in an economy that we want to be sustainable and that we know will be increasingly digital!

name: Vlad-Marius BOTOŞ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it has been more than ten months since we have been living in difficult times for everyone. The pandemic made things stop working the way we used to: we work online, we buy online, we even participate in online cultural events, online medical consultations.  The need to adapt quickly to this way of life has highlighted numerous problems of the online environment. That is why I am pleased to see that the regulation of consumer rights related to this environment is one of the priorities set out by the Commission. It will certainly be one of the difficult areas to regulate, especially if we take into account that the digital market is not limited to the European Union.  Relations between buyers and sellers or producers are already moving beyond traditional national or European cooperation, and we will have to enter the field of international trade relations. We will also have to address the issue of those who cannot be consumers because they do not have access to this market due to lack of infrastructure, technical facilities or knowledge to navigate such a complex environment. Another particularly important point will be the swift implementation of European legislation in the Member States and the effective support of supervisory authorities to ensure that consumer protection regulations are applied. Every consumer in the European Union has the same rights at theoretical level, but we know very well that there are major differences both in the transposition of legislation and in its application and market surveillance. That is why we will need to find specific interoperable digital tools that work across the entire European single market. We will only be able to ensure the same rights for all European consumers by finding ways to ensure that all Member States have at their disposal both the technical knowledge and facilities and the necessary capabilities to verify and test potentially dangerous products circulating in the European common market.  We will have to be open in our approach, to be innovative, to be able to make the best use of new digital technologies, interoperable databases that can be the key to ensuring the rights of all European consumers, regardless of the region they are in or how they purchase their products.

name: David CORMAND
text: Madam President, Commissioner Reynders, I thank you for the presentation of your report. There is little good news in the difficult times we are going through, to dare to affirm when a sign of hope crosses our troubled sky. And the agenda we are discussing here is moving in the right direction. It is going in the right direction but, as always, words must be transformed into actions. I think the debate we have is an exciting debate. I understand in some of the speeches that there would be some kind of opposition between the ecological issue and the social issue. In reality, it is the same subject: how to destroy the planet with poor quality products and to push for consumption, especially the most fragile, of products that have a reduced lifespan. It is a social issue and it is an ecological issue. So our job as a legislator is to make rules, otherwise we are useless. Rules that allow both this consideration of the ecological issue, but also the rules that protect consumers and, from this point of view, I stress that, yes, there are vulnerable consumers, and the commission in which I sit is that of the internal market and consumer protection. The reason we have decided, in our wisdom for years, to provide for the protection of consumers, is because there was a reason to do so. The whole point is to make the ecological question of safeguarding life on Earth and the social question work together, all in an economic framework to which we must give meaning, because today this senseless economic model is annihilating, including the European economy, including European SMEs. And so I plead, Commissioner, for optimal ambition in the report on which you are working, on which we will work together, the future of our continent's economy, the future of the planet and also the protection of consumers, and especially the most fragile, are at stake.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, we believe it is necessary to strengthen the financial and human resources of national supervisory authorities by increasing their competences and cooperation between entities, in particular with the development of joint actions at cross-border and online level. We also advocate the need to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of controls in order to ensure the safety of products marketed in a traditional and online way, over the Internet, as proactive measures to combat misleading practices and disinformation by protecting consumers. However, we do not follow up on minimum proposals for legislative harmonisation, in the logic of market and profit, by overlapping EU legislation with national legislation that is more advanced with regard to consumer protection. But our contribution to this debate also involves drawing attention to the necessary fight against programmed obsolescence.  In this context, there is a fundamental, incomprehensible and intolerable problem, which has to do with the fact that large economic groups continue to introduce characteristics in products that deliberately cause shorter validity, either by integrating parts, preventing them from being replaced, even by using programming specifically designed to reduce the responsiveness of appliances at the end of a certain time. This use of programmed obsolescence requires an appropriate response, with its immediate prohibition and the promotion of a culture of repair and reuse. We will therefore be contributing to more sustainable and socially just policies.

name: Kris PEETERS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are experiencing many changes that affect our consumption patterns. The COVID–19 crisis, digitisation and the green transition are some examples of this.  Consumers want custom rules that meet their needs. They need to be given more clout to contribute to the green transition. This means that consumers need to be better informed and that there is a right to repair that facilitates the transition to a circular economy. Artificial ageing also needs to be addressed. Misleading consumers by deliberately shortening the life of products is an unfair commercial practice that we must ban.  It is important that the new rules encourage consumers to make sustainable choices. Online, too, citizens want to enjoy the same high level of protection. Consumers are increasingly buying products and services online. In this context, we are seeing an increase in unauthorised activities such as online fraud, the dissemination of false information and certain forms of profiling. These practices affect consumer choice and do not belong in Europe.  In addition, there are specific groups of consumers with specific needs. Children, people with limited digital literacy, families in difficult financial situations are some examples of this. They ask for a customized protection.  The COVID–19 crisis also exposed some gaps in European consumer law. Let's learn from this and take this lesson into the future.  Finally, we must not forget that we always ensure a level playing field when implementing measures. The new consumer agenda is ambitious but necessary. Consumer choice plays a crucial role in the recovery after the COVID–19 crisis, the green and digital transformation. That is why we must build high-quality and high-quality consumer protection in the future, and I am sure, Commissioner, that you will succeed.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course we are debating this evening, immediately after a very important sustainability report, behold, an intention by the Commission to find new measures to increase consumer protection. Obviously, I, as Vice-President of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, have always said that there is a need to strike a perfect balance between consumer protection and the development, of course, of businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and I am pleased, Commissioner, that you, in the statements you have made several times in the debates in the IMCO Committee , you said that you are thinking, through the regulations you make, not to bring administrative burdens, additional costs to SMEs. However, we must recognise that this COVID crisis has shown us that there are vulnerabilities in terms of consumer protection. And if you, the Commission, have proposed five directions for increasing consumer protection – in one of them you have explained that there is shared responsibility for the Member States, obviously – but, Commissioner, you have answered many questions and maybe you will answer and this evening the Member States are no longer able to make bilateral agreements, trade agreements are signed, negotiated by the European Commission. And then, Commissioner, do you think in this programme to increase consumer protection to put into these trade agreements more concrete measures, by which to ensure, on the one hand, the security of citizens in the consumption of products or services, at the same time, fair competition in the internal market with businesses in the European Union?  And I would also like, Commissioner, to congratulate you for thinking of making a proposal for a directive on collective legal action, because, yes, the consumer, and small and medium-sized enterprises have very high costs to make legal action each. I would like you to tell us if you have a deadline, a deadline, when you think that this directive will be, because on the one hand it costs and takes a long time for legal action, because in so many Member States, as is my country, we do not have specialised commercial tribunals. That is why, I believe, Commissioner, that we need to have traceability – and this can be done through labelling – and to have control – and this can be done through a customs union set up and through the national authorities who have to control what we decide here.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: – (beginning of the speech when the micro is switched off) ... Complaints have been received in Germany alone at consumer centres about travel companies and airlines this year. When airlines such as Lufthansa and Air France benefit from multibillion-dollar bailouts, they are less sure of the refunds. We find that whoever receives billions in aid from the state has a special responsibility for the climate and its customers. Many customers have been waiting in vain for months to get their travel expenses reimbursed. Many people who have to turn around every euro three times due to COVID have spent their savings on annual leave. This money must not now disappear into airline balance sheets. We must, in principle, strengthen the rights of travellers in the EU. It is therefore an aberration that the Member States have been blocking the Passenger Directive since 2013 and that there has been little progress on rail passenger rights. While airlines are being rescued without any significant conditions, the rights of travellers are being trampled underfoot. The Greens support the call by consumer protection organisations to change this. The prepayment rule must be abolished. Instead of months in advance, the money for tickets should be paid just before the trip. Travellers need to be better protected from the insolvency of airlines and travel companies. Let us make the European Union together the Consumer Protection Union!

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: - Dear Chairman, the new consumer strategy presented by the European Commission is a strategic document aimed at ensuring a high level of consumer protection and their rights. In the circumstances of an unprecedented crisis, this is not an easy task at all. European consumers, 450 million of them, as a weaker contracting party in a legal relationship with traders must enjoy qualified redress.  It is through effective redress and a comprehensive consumer protection policy that the single market can function properly and effectively. Empowering consumers, protecting their security and economic interests are priority policy objectives of the European Union. During the COVID-19 crisis, consumer policy has proven crucial to ensuring reimbursement of costs for cancelling services, combating the spread of disinformation and UTPs, in particular those selling fraudulent or non-compliants' medical equipment.  However, while the European Union has a long tradition of protecting consumer rights, the crisis has shown us that there is room for improvement in the consumer protection system as well. In this regard, the European Commission has correctly detected the key priorities it wishes to achieve over the next five-year period, in particular the green transition, digital transformation, level of redress and protection of vulnerable groups. In doing so, I would certainly highlight the issue of digital transformation and the new challenges emerging in the European market such as the issue of selling defective products, spreading fake news that we have to fight with all the instruments we have at our disposal. In doing so, I would point out that the legal protections that consumers should enjoy should be uniform across the European Union so that consumers in Croatia, Germany, Italy or the Netherlands enjoy exactly the same rights. In this regard, the European Union should continue to build a consumer policy based on the scientific background at the heart of which is the consumer, which sees entrepreneurs as partners in the implementation of this policy, not as enemies.  As a member of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee, I welcome the new strategy and at the same time call for us to use the lessons we learned in the crisis to ensure a high level of consumer redress.

name: Marc ANGEL
text: – Madam President, a fantastic achievement of the European Union has been the development of a robust consumer law acquis, providing rights to consumers and also empowering them to make the right decisions. EU consumer law should largely be based on the principle that well-informed consumers make the best choices and that they can trust in an effective law enforcement. Commissioner, like my S&D colleagues and many others, I welcome the update of the Consumer Agenda. I would like to highlight two specific issues. First of all, the notions of ‘average consumer’ and ‘vulnerable consumer’ which are used in EU law. I believe that, in the digital world, these notions need to be called into question because the consumer is faced with constant monitoring and manipulation. Consumers are in a state of permanent digital vulnerability, or ‘vulnerability by default’. Therefore, we need a shift away from the average consumer to the principle of ‘protection by default or by design’. This would be a clear and real reaction on the information asymmetries we face. I also believe, like many of us here, that legislation without effective enforcement puts at risk consumers’ trust and confidence in the single market. And here I arrive at my second topic. According to the regulation on air passengers’ rights, passengers should be reimbursed in seven days for cancelled flights. We all know that. Even if we intend to help airlines overcome the extraordinary circumstances of the COVID-19 pandemic and protect the employees – there are hundreds and thousands of employees in these companies – this can only happen without harming consumer rights.  I believe that the recommendation of the Commission on reimbursement for cancelled transport services in the context of the pandemic was necessary. However, on my written question, Commissioner Vălean answered that the responsibility of enforcement is linked to the national enforcement bodies and that the Commission considers appropriate actions only in case of a systematic failure. Well, I think there is a clear systematic failure in this case, but we do not see an effective reaction to that by the Commission, so we should avoid such situations. If we want to keep consumers’ trust and confidence in the single market we have to do that. I hope that these examples help to clarify how we can develop our Consumer Agenda beyond 2020. Consumer rights are in the DNA of our socialists and democrats, and together with many colleagues and you, Commissioner, we will advance and protect them.

name: Claude GRUFFAT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Europeans want to consume more local and more sustainable. They see the future benefits for their portfolios and the planet. The planet's biodiversity is its biodiversity, the fertility of its soils, its healthy air, its clean drinking water and of course the living environment of its inhabitants. But let's face it, at the time of purchase, you have to be terribly clever to find your way through the information provided. Who can say that they feel informed about the ecological and social balance of what they buy or consume? The past century has been one of all-round consumption and at all costs in some way. Now let's enter the era of conscious consumption, responsible consumption, more social, greener, more "sustainable climate". This will only be achieved through clear and transparent information on the origin and composition of the products. How much natural resources do you consume for a particular manufactured product? What social practices in the manufacturing chain? What is the carbon footprint? What are the possibilities for repair? How long does the product last? How much of the actual recycling? And for food: beyond provenance and nutritional value, what chemical processes throughout production? What residual dose of pesticides in the diet? Colleagues, our consumption patterns must change urgently. It is by relying on the intelligence and knowledge of consumers, through transparent and accessible information that we will ultimately produce more local and responsible.

name: Antonius MANDERS
text: Mr President, Commissioner Reynders, thank you for explaining this ambitious agenda. However, the desired result is in the effect and we expect something from you there. Without consumer confidence, there is no market. So consumer confidence needs to be strengthened, especially when it comes to digital purchases. I believe that consumers should be better protected online than offline. Offline you see what you buy. You can feel it. You can see it. Online, you don't know where your store is. Is it in China or is it on the corner? A survey in Germany indicates that one in four consumers are faced with online fraud, of which 30% actually lose money because they fall for online fraud. I think we need to ensure that we have fantastic protection. I also do not know exactly how, but perhaps due to a delay at banks so that the money can be reclaimed later, because if you have lost your money, then you as a consumer have hardly any rights, because go for a small purchase litigating with a seller in China or wherever. Then we hope that you will come up with proposals that are cast into a regulation, full harmonised legislation in a single market, and not that Member States should transposing the directives, giving us a kind of Scottish blanket with all sorts of different levels of legislation, so that consumers don't know where they are, but neither do businesses. Regulations are therefore good for businesses and good for consumers.  Promoting safe products is very important. But what is also very important – we have seen this with COVID–19 – is to promote a healthy lifestyle. And perhaps we can encourage that with the proposals you are going to make, and we trust them. Then there must be reciprocity, in the sense that companies from outside the European Union that offer products in the European Union and make money there must fully comply with all the European protection legislation we know.  I would also like to say that large companies have no influence on democracy, and a great example of this is that after ten years the universal charger has still not been introduced because Apple does not want it, and that is actually a disgrace to democracy.

name: Salvatore DE MEO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years online consumption - as has been said - has grown considerably and more and more European citizens are relying on the web to shop. It should be added that the restrictions resulting from the measures necessary to contain COVID have pushed consumers further towards this commercial mode, increasing online purchases, which since 2009 have even doubled, from 32 to 60 %. The new consumer agenda comes at the right time, because it must be recognised that existing legislation is no longer adequate to fully protect our consumers, just as businesses cannot be fully satisfied with their access to the digital market either. At the moment the goods we buy online are not subject to controls comparable to those that traditional distributors have to comply with and this often causes great dissatisfaction with many goods and services bought online. In the case of food purchases, the greatest risk is of incurring low-quality products or counterfeiting, with potential risks also to health. We must pay attention to initiatives aimed at modernising digital services, with both consumer and producer protection as a priority. Digital platforms, whose role has increased considerably in recent years, must be more responsible for the services they offer and we must pay close attention to vulnerable users in order to protect them from fraud or impropriety. We must combat unfair commercial practices that violate the right of consumers to make an informed choice, by abusing their behavioural inclinations or by altering their decision-making processes with covert or misleading advertising. Finally, I welcome the fact that global producers, such as China, are ensuring full cooperation in guarantee checks and that, therefore, foreign products that are placed in the European single market do not harm either buyers or our companies operating and producing in Europe.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. An essential condition for making the Digital Single Market more attractive and dynamic is that both citizens and businesses have confidence in e-commerce. For a long time, all signs have pointed in the direction of the need to modernise certain consumer protection rules in order to meet the current challenges. I am pleased that the Commission has also seen the need for changes and, as a result, the new consumer strategy that we are discussing today has been presented, which I can only welcome.  I believe that better enforcement of the rules is a more effective means of redress. Deeper knowledge of consumer rights can strengthen consumer confidence and a sense of security. However, the rules can only be effective if they allow consumers to easily obtain redress in the event of an infringement and can be implemented by national authorities. The strategy tries to answer important consumer protection issues that are emerging today. Markets continue to develop and change rapidly, mainly due to the effects of the coronavirus epidemic. The pandemic has increased consumers' need for transparency, sustainability and comfort. The biggest advantages will be given to companies that gain consumer trust, do not regret the investment needed to achieve a smooth and trouble-free shopping experience, and prioritise the health and safety of consumers.  I very much ask the Commission to pay attention to consumer safety, in particular the cybersecurity aspects of consumer protection, and to continue to monitor consumer markets in order to identify emerging problems.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: membre de la Commission. – Madame la Présidente, Mesdames, Messieurs les députés, je voudrais vous remercier à nouveau de ce débat comme du débat précédent et je me réjouis que votre assemblée s’engage pleinement dans la mise en œuvre du nouvel agenda du consommateur. Comme je l’ai mentionné au début de notre débat, votre rôle dans l’élaboration des priorités et des actions présentées dans cet agenda est primordial et je voudrais revenir sur un certain nombre d’aspects en saluant d’abord le fait que vous vous penchez non seulement sur la politique que nous pourrions mener à l’intérieur de l’Union européenne, mais aussi sur la façon de poursuivre cette politique dans des accords internationaux, je pense notamment aux accords de commerce. Un certain nombre de politiques devront effectivement être utilisées pour atteindre nos objectifs et pas seulement spécifiquement la politique du consommateur dans l’Union européenne. Il y a d’autres cadres bien entendu à utiliser de la même manière. Maintenant, je voudrais, comme je le disais, revenir sur quelques questions évoquées. EU harmonisation has brought solid progress for consumer policy. Many EU consumer laws follow this approach, such as the Directive on pre—contractual information and rights of withdrawal for online contracts. However, when proposing new legislation we need to carefully consider the level of protection in the different Member States. Sometimes minimum harmonisation is chosen so that Member States have a possibility to go beyond common EU requirements in certain areas. Therefore, the Commission will decide on the level of harmonisation of its proposal on a case-by-case basis.  We need to work on concrete enforcement of the rights enshrined in EU law for consumers, and for protection of consumers. For example, the Commission opened 11 infringement proceedings against Member States that adopted national measures contrary to the Package Travel Directive during the pandemic.  Four proceedings are still open, and in addition I wrote on 30 October to 10 Member States that are now back in compliance with EU rules but that had adopted national legislation contrary to the Package Travel Directive. I urged them to take measures to remedy the situation created by their past legislation that ran contrary to Union law and to make sure that consumers effectively get their rights in accordance with the Package Travel Directive.  I also reminded them of the primacy of EU law and some will continue to work, to organise, of course, protection of consumers, but more than that, to go to real enforcement of consumer rights. And we will pay attention to some categories of consumers, vulnerable ones like children, but we will also pay attention to other kinds of people – I’m thinking about people having difficulties to use digital tools, like people with disabilities. For them, we need to organise better accessibility.  The Geo-blocking Regulation was adopted in 2018. As explained in the Consumer Agenda, the Commission is evaluating its impact and will publish a report. This report will include an assessment of the possible application of new rules to certain electronically supplied services which offer copyright protected content, such as music, e-books, software and online games, as well as of services in sectors such as transport and audiovisual.  The Commission is of course strongly committed to addressing all kinds of unfair commercial practices, including practices suggesting to consumers that goods have the same composition and characteristics when this is not the case. In this context, the Commission will continue to work with the Member States and their competent authorities in order to ensure correct and timely transposition of the new rules in the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive. These rules have been introduced by the Better Enforcement and Modernisation Directive that will apply across the EU from May 2022.  Moreover, as dual-quality cases are cross-border cases by nature, the Commission will facilitate and support the work of the competent authorities of the Member States under the new Consumer Protection Cooperation (CPC) Regulation.  As announced in the Agenda, the Commission will come with further concrete proposals in the following months and years, and in the second quarter of the next year three legislative proposals will be put on the table: an initiative to empower consumers in the green transition, a review of the Consumer Credit Directive and a review of the General Product Safety Directive. So I’m looking forward to working further with you in the preparation and follow-up of these proposals.  Our goal is to build a real trust in consumers in the good functioning of the internal market and in the safety and sustainability of all the products proposed in the EU, offline and online, and of course, I’m sure that we will work together to build such a trust inside the European Union. So thank you again for this opportunity to present to you the Consumer Agenda. Thank you for your attention, and thank you for your proposals.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Pablo ARIAS ECHEVERRÍA
text: in writing. – The COVID pandemic and the economic crisis it has generated are affecting consumers in an unprecedented way.  We need an ambitious European strategy that protects consumers and empowers and gives them confidence in decision-making, as consumers in turn will be key to economic recovery.  We also need our consumers to be protected in the digital realm; following the principle of what is illegal offline is also online, we must ensure security when making online purchases.  This is something that we have already addressed in the report with recommendations to the Commission on the Digital Services Act: an improvement in the functioning of the single market, but which we must continue to develop in this new strategy.  Finally, it should be noted that in this process we must include everyone, and special attention must be paid to those consumers who are minors or live with disabilities.

name: Cristina MAESTRE MARTÍN DE ALMAGRO
text: in writing. – The European Commission published on 13 November the New Consumer Agenda, which aims to put consumers at the centre of digital and ecological transitions as the engine of the recovery of this crisis.  The COVID-19 crisis has highlighted the vulnerability that consumers find themselves in with respect to counterfeit products, cancellation of travel, backwaters on the network, etc. This agenda envisages taking note of the situations that have occurred during this pandemic and sets out the roadmap to be followed over the next five years. Consumption accounts for 50% of Europe's GDP, so safeguarding consumers and trying to give them high protection is essential.  The New Consumer Agenda covers five key areas. These are: ecological transition, digital transformation, respect for consumer rights, protection of the needs of vulnerable consumers and international cooperation.  With the rise of e-commerce, we must protect citizens who make purchases through this route. The Commission therefore plans to develop an action plan with China in 2021 to improve the safety of products sold online.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Rapporteur. Madam Vice-President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, a warm greeting to God, dear Mairead McGuinness. I believe it is the first time that you are no longer sitting up there as Vice-President in your new role, but here with the Commissioners. Welcome and I look forward to a good cooperation with you in the future. Let me say a few sentences to what we are debating today. The MiFID adjustment that we are now talking about is just a few things. MiFID itself is a very large, very complex piece of legislation, and the Commission has rightly identified a few points where we now also need to provide answers in view of the situation in 2020. I just want to pick out a few points. Firstly, I am pleased that we can now speak in plenary. I would say very clearly that at no time in committee was it possible to even talk briefly about this dossier, that the Commission can imagine its issues, that we can also talk.  I do not think that is acceptable. The way in which the European Parliament operates is very, very unsatisfactory at this point, to put it very clearly. I do not think that this is acceptable for us to legislate on a permanent basis without even having a debate. And I even had to fight for us to talk about it here in plenary today, otherwise it would have gone through everything without debate. That is not the way to go. Secondly, we must also consider: is it COVID-relevant here or is it not COVID-relevant what we do? I believe that the COVID pandemic has clearly shown one thing: companies that were well positioned even before the crisis have so far got through quite well. But when companies start adapting to new challenges, they have a very difficult time. And that is where the Commission's proposal is all about. How can we facilitate companies' access to capital and how can we facilitate investor access to companies?  And that is precisely the challenge at stake, which we must also answer at this time. That is why it is specifically about: how do we better bring supply and demand together? I would also like to say quite frankly that this is not about undermining investor protection, as some people claim. Yes, sorry, if we no longer overwaste a professional investor who really does nothing else every day, who knows what it is all about – I can't say otherwise – then it is not a softening of consumer protection, but the challenge is to give professional investors the opportunity to make a decision, but not to overwhelm them by constantly being overwhelmed with new information. This is not deregulation, it is adaptation. The same applies when it comes to allowing new medium-sized enterprises on the capital market. I do not know where the problem is. I am surprised that, for example, an ESMA dossier is not accepted here, which clearly states that our regulations make it so difficult for new companies – especially the excellently positioned mid-caps, which are world market leaders in their segment, even though they employ only a few people – to access the capital market. The Commission is taking up what ESMA says, and SUDDENLY ESMA no longer plays a role. While on the third issue in the Commission proposal, on the position limits, what ESMA says is rejected in bausch and arc. I wonder: where are we here? I looked at commodity futures markets in Chicago in 2008; I looked at the preparation of the MiFID commodity futures markets in London so that we could get the best out of the people of Europe, namely no speculation on food. And now there are even organisations such as Finance Watch, which we finance from the European Union budget and which are sending around here sending around and claiming that we are allowing food speculation. It is clear in the Commission's proposal: no! It is clear from the Council decision: no! It is clear in Parliament's decision: No! What is it all about? It is about us wanting to take the transformation of our energy supply forward – in Europe. We need to give small new entrants – not the large electricity companies, whom we are making life harder with the Commission proposal by examining certain exemptions more rigorously in the future – new entrants – a small cooperative that operates its wind farm, a small group that operates a solar system – to survive in the market.  The shops will take place, either in the European Union with the euro, with European partners, or they will be hedged outside Europe, with investors from other countries outside the European Union. Is that our ambition? If we want the Green Deal to succeed, we must allow it to happen. I understand that some Members have ideological problems here. But my dear friends, this is not about ideology. It is a question of preparing Europe, making it capable of action, of strengthening the euro, of making our business here in the European Union attractive to investors from the European Union. I therefore ask that we support the decision of the ECON Committee here in plenary.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank you very much Madam Vice-President, thank you colleagues and thank you Mr Ferber for your warm welcome back to my old home. It’s very hot in here and perhaps this debate will be a heated one but a very necessary one. And as it is my first return to Parliament: I do miss you somewhat, but I hope that I can do good service for Europe now as Commissioner. You’ve dealt with some of the issues, but I want to just say that this debate is important because we need clarity, and therefore I hope I can provide that to you. I want to thank Mr Ferber for his work and for this report. It is a very important part of our Capital Markets Recovery Package, and this was proposed in July. And we want it to help the recovery from this COVID-19 crisis and we want it agreed as soon as possible, because time is of the essence in terms of getting capital flowing to where it’s needed. There are some concerns, and I’m sure I’ll hear them spelled out in detail this evening and I will listen very carefully to them. But first, let me address some issues, which may help our understanding. The first point is that our recovery from this crisis has to be green: I’ve made that statement in every comment I’ve made publicly since becoming Commissioner. The green energy transition needs to be accompanied by greater liquidity and transparency in the markets for energy derivatives. Producers of green energy, electricity from wind or solar, need to negotiate forward contracts. These contracts secure a minimum price for energy produced from renewable sources, and these forward supply contracts are derivative contracts. They secure a certain price for green energy. These forward contracts serve the real economy by providing some certainty to investors in the growing renewable energy sector. This is not about price speculation; it’s about certainty for those who are investing. Second, to be effective, forward supply contracts need to be liquid and available on a new generation of energy exchanges. If we maintain the current low position limit of 25% of market participants, these energy exchanges simply will not take off. And this is particularly important for energy contracts in smaller Member States, as contracts for forward delivery of green energy are still in their infancy. At most, there are often two or three market participants offering such hedging tools, and this means that all of these market players would be in breach of the 25% position limit even before the market takes off, and I’m sure you agree that is not what we want to see. My third point is that there is a clear link to the Covid pandemic. Energy prices have been volatile due to the more erratic demand for energy. Production capacity has ebbed and flowed in line with Covid restrictions. It is crucial that we protect the income for renewable energy producers when demand for energy is volatile. Fourthly, I want to be very clear that the Commission is not using the Covid crisis as a cover to introduce opportunities for food or energy price speculation. The proposed amendments do not apply to agriculture derivatives or derivatives for food for human consumption. The proposed amendments also do not apply to mature energy derivative markets. These markets will remain subject to the rules agreed with Parliament in 2016. Securing a decent price for the delivery of green energy is not price speculation. So in conclusion, inaction on energy derivative reform means that there are no transparent energy exchanges offering derivative contracts for electricity produced in smaller Member States. In our preparatory work we have presented evidence to this effect. Some will argue that there is no rush in reforming energy markets and that volatility is not going to last. I would just say that the COVID-19 crisis hit us harder and over a longer time period than any of us expected, and indeed, when my staff started working on this, this was not the case. So we are living with a more prolonged situation. Therefore, we cannot afford to postpone this important reform of energy markets for another year. The proposed measures are more important than ever. They should be adopted by the end of this year to make it easier for capital markets to support European businesses to recover from the crisis. Thank you, and I look forward to what I hope will be a very stimulating debate and where there is better understanding of the issues that may be in play at the moment.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Rapporteur Markus Ferber, warm congratulations on this excellent report with the aim of reshaping the future and on the impassioned speech. We need to turn many screws to help citizens and businesses get out of the crisis. The NextGenerationEU investment plan, the Green Deal, the EU long-term budget and our monetary policy measures must and will also be followed by the financial market, and we want to put it more at the service of our common future. Indeed, unlike the 2008 financial crisis, when some banks were the source of the problem, the financial sector is now part of the solution. We have already successfully tightened the first screw in the banking sector. The banking rules have been revised at record speed to mobilise €450 billion in additional loans. We have preferred the extended support factor for SMEs to make it easier and more widely available for loans, pension loans and infrastructure financing. We have relaxed the capital rules for software investments in order to provide an answer to digitalization. Turning the second screw is just about, namely the package of measures for the recovery of capital markets. We are adopting this Ferber report in order to reduce unnecessary administrative burdens, promote the recapitalisation of companies and strengthen the international role of the euro by supporting the development of the market for energy derivatives. We are working on the right dosage of the securitisation financial instrument, which I am negotiating with Paul Tang, in order to increase support for SMEs, further boost lending and create new investment opportunities. We are developing an EU reconstruction prospectus to help companies raise capital in the form of shares, rather than continuing to get into debt. We have tackled many screws, many areas. We are not finished yet, but we must use this time to reduce the risks, to eliminate the problems and to actively address the challenges. We must not waste any time. Confidence and commitment are required.

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, this MiFID quick fix aims to support business suffering from the COVID impact. That has been heard from the Commission. My political group fully supports measures helping business, in particular in these difficult times of COVID-19. That is what business needs – financial support – but it needs it now in the days, weeks and months to come. That is why the S&D Group took the lead for the EU recovery fund and welcomes the EIB’s EUR 25 billion pan-European Guarantee Fund supporting SMEs. At the same time, we are fully aware that there is a deeper structural problem with a lack of equity financing of the European Union businesses. This needs structural solutions, with the right level of investor protection. This is the reason why my Group wants the Commission to come forward with an ambitious reform of the MiFID rules by mid next year, after full consultation of all stakeholders, and based on a serious impact assessment. Indeed, structural long existing problems cannot be solved in a hasty way via a quick fix. That is the reason why we had rather strong reservations around the MiFID quick fix from the start. We fail to see the clear link between this proposal and the COVID-19 crisis. In particular as these rules will only be applicable at the earliest second half 2021. So let’s be clear: we will not allow the COVID-19 crisis to be used as an excuse for a deregulation agenda, and this is a real threat here. This quick fix, or, as some have proposed, a mini review should not become a maxi review. Therefore my Group, together with the Greens, tabled a very targeted amendment on the review of the position limits in derivative contracts. This should make it possible to address a specific problem in emerging energy markets, which are suffering the impact of COVID, instead of removing a balanced system which we have agreed during the last mandate period.  Secondly, if we want to convince investors to invest in the market, transparency around the costs is critical. Unbundling rules are introduced by MiFID II to allow for a more transparent reporting of costs, and that has to be accepted also in the future.
