Therefore, we proposed a strong review clause and this reform needs to be well prepared based on facts and data and after consultation with all the relevant stakeholders. As the S&D Group, we are looking forward to such a balanced reform which also protects investors and helps businesses. We are also ready for cooperation in the future.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, greetings from Dublin, and first and foremost, may I just take the opportunity to wish Commissioner McGuinness success in her new appointment. It’s the first opportunity to formally congratulate you in a plenary session, so I wish you well. The response to the economic crisis caused by the global pandemic needs to be multifaceted. It needs to embrace both public and private national governments and the European institutions. And the European Union has responded quickly and generously to provide support to the broader economies, including a temporary state aid framework, the European Central Bank’s pandemic emergency purchase programme, and the European Investment Bank’s EUR 200 billion support plan for small and medium-sized enterprises. Aside, of course, from the injections of public money, it is important that the market as well contributes to the recovery, and the amendments to the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive were timely, and the Parliament did react quickly and in a spirit of cooperation to ensure these amendments could take effect as soon as possible. These amendments will provide investors with greater flexibility and will also ease some of the burdensome requirements, thereby freeing up resources and allowing investors to contribute to the recapitalisation of our small and medium-size enterprises, which are the backbone of the European economy. I suppose I am disappointed I did put down some amendments, Commissioner, to this particular report around the issue of dual listing of companies on different stock exchanges – so, for example, Irish companies dual listed in Dublin and in the UK – and certainly it is regrettable that they weren’t taken on board. I know that the European Securities and Markets Authority did bring forward partial solutions, but that does not resolve the issue around Irish companies listed in Dublin and in the UK in euros. So I would really urge the Commission to look at that. And I know that Brexit is a word that, you know, is very sensitive at the moment because we around the final negotiations, but I do believe that we can’t let any inhibitants to capital and liquidity and access to same, and if this issue is not addressed around dual listing of companies, well then it could tie up a huge amount of capital that is required by Irish companies. Also, Commissioner, the pandemic shows the urgency around the capital markets union. We all need to ensure that there’s no inhibitants or blocks to access to finance, and the Covid pandemic has brought forward a certain element of urgency in us responding to the needs of the broader economy out there. But when we return to some form of normality, we have to insist that the capital markets union is a vibrant market, that it ensures that there is access to finance and also that there is accessibility to trading: in other words, people can invest knowing that there’s certainty and they can trade. So I would urge that we do not relax, that we stay in tune, and we ensure that the capital market union is a priority.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Mr Ferber, thank you very much for your report. The Financial Markets Directive is an important piece of legislation aimed at promoting the development of currently underdeveloped capital markets in the EU, while ensuring investor and consumer protection. Especially in the age of Corona, it is important to ensure that our European companies can recapitalise quickly and safely. However, the history of this directive is also a prime example of institutional uncertainty. One step forward, two back. It was not until 2018 that we drastically tightened financial regulation. We have forced the financial sector to shower its customers with hundreds of pages of paperwork, as well as registering confidential phone calls between companies and customers. No one believes that this somehow protects the interests of customers. The only ones who benefited from MiFID were the financial advisers, who collected huge consulting fees by helping the financial sector to comply with the rules they had drawn up themselves. But then a small miracle happened. In a rare moment of listening to her bad conscience, the Commission recognised her mistake and proposed a review. Unfortunately, this is now being postponed until 2021. However, given that, in COVID times, small and medium-sized enterprises are having a very difficult time finding investment capital on the market – partly because of MiFID – this Parliament is now trying to carefully debureaucratise part of the financial market – and we welcome that. Unfortunately, the rapporteur has now withdrawn many of his good proposals in order to please the left – and we regret that. However, we expect the directive to be reviewed next year and further deregulated and de-bureaucratised. That is why we also recommend that we vote in favour of the directive. But what if the next financial crisis breaks out in the coming years? Given the huge increase in public and private debt across the EU, that would not even be a surprise. Will we then increase the regulatory burden again? I am sure that the consulting industry would be enthusiastic. For once, what our companies and investors really need is regulatory security. Overturning the rules does not create confidence in the EU institutions. On the contrary, the more we regulate at European level, the more we experience the centrifugal forces of an EU that is still struggling to hold together. And you all don't want that. Here, as so often, less is more.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, welcome and good luck in this first appearance in the plenary session of the European Parliament. You inherit a dossier which is not easy in this House: there are many groups that we do not like the quick fix that the Commission has presented. I think you are aware of this, because we have the impression that we are walking a path that will dismantle everything that had cost us so much to build from the G20 after the previous financial crisis and some of these measures are clearly on the way to deregulating finances, in a path that seems very dangerous to us. I enter MiFID, to begin with, the limit regime of positions that was introduced to avoid speculation of raw materials in the energy sector. We cannot forget that this measure was introduced precisely after the food price crisis in 2009 and 2011 — so as not to repeat this issue. The Commission contends, and today reminds us, that the proposed changes to this scheme are carefully calibrated, because they will not apply to agricultural commodity derivatives; it is true, but what is completely ignored is the strong interrelationship that exists between energy markets and food markets.  Clearly, if there is a speculative attack on energy prices this is going to affect the food markets, something that Oxfam and Finance Watch have reminded us of, and they are right, Mr Ferber. In addition, I have to say, Commissioner, that the MiFID Directive states in a very clear way that, before touching this regime, you should have submitted an environmental impact assessment, which you have not done. I know we have the ESMA study, but the MiFID Directive does not mandata ESMA to do this, it makes you mandata, and we don't have this impact assessment study yet. Therefore, this reform does not satisfy us in any way. But there are also other measures that are added to these , as I said before , very worrying, for example: how is it possible for the Commission to introduce, in another reform, preferential treatment for synthetic securitisation, in which risk transfer is achieved through the use of derivatives, when we know that derivatives in financial markets were at the centre of the financial crisis? Or, for example, what justifies the proposal that the securitisation of delinquent loans be treated better in terms of capital requirements? We have the impression that we are giving a covert subsidy to banking in exchange for increased systemic risk, and that is a profound mistake.  These measures do not help finance the real economy of families, they only increase risk and financing, and what I think we have to ask ourselves is: when the next financial crisis comes — and we know that we have very significant risks in front of us – are these measures that we are taking to help us better deal with the financial crisis or will we be in worse condition? We certainly believe that on this path we are not doing well and, in the specific case of MiFID, the reasonable, sensible thing to do, would be to postpone this partial reform, to wait for the comprehensive reform that we have to do, for you to be able to make your environmental impact assessment, and thereby to face a comprehensive reform of the Directive. These reforms in a hurry and running in this way of regimes as, as, as delicate and important as that of the limits of positions I do not think they lead us on the right path.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, this document is another one of several quick fixes, quick arrangements, which have been put to this Parliament in recent times, all of them in order to deregulate the financial system and all of them retreating into many of the most important consensuses which, in spite of everything, at least in the speeches, have been built on the regulation of the financial system following the financial crisis and we see all of them being reversed today.  Information to investor clients is now no longer information, it is not transparency; it is unnecessary bureaucracy and therefore touches to cut it. It is not quite possible that capital markets will work better, giving less information to customers and researchers, but that is what has been approved. It is not only proposed in this report, but also in a report which has passed very discreetly on prospects.  We are also retreating into the very organisation of the financial system. We know that derivatives were a product that was at the heart of the last financial crisis. We know that securitisation was also one of the key elements in the instability that led to the last financial crisis. We know, with regard to agricultural goods and energy goods, that we have already had several demonstrations of the very strong correlation between these markets, including the crises that have already been mentioned.  On this, there has been no impact study, because a quick consultation with some representatives of the financial industry is not an impact assessment. It is only the European institutions, the Commission and the European Parliament, who make their work the direct representation of the lobbyists of the financial system, in line with what is the worst tradition of public action in regulating the financial system.  There is a reason why we are having all these quick arrangements, now in a hurry, in the midst of the COVID crisis and that reason has nothing to do with the economic recovery, it has nothing to do with getting capital to small and medium-sized enterprises, which is the usual conversation whenever these proposals come up on the table.  It has to do with two very simple issues: using the economic crisis to push this agenda of deregulation of the financial system against everything we learned in the last financial crisis, and two, taking advantage of the fact that people are distracted by more serious events and more media events to push a deeply irresponsible agenda and that people would refuse and refuse if they were informed of it. This Parliament will be responsible for the consequences of these rapid arrangements which will very quickly damage the regulation of the financial system in Europe and the world.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, we are at the centre of the biggest crisis since World War II - both economic and social. As in any crisis, those who are rich become even richer, those who are poor become even poorer. On this day in the European Union, 700,000 citizens live homeless, live on the street. We have 700,000 homeless people.  Only a few citizens in this world have a wealth greater than half the population. When we talk about entrepreneurship, the most important thing for every entrepreneur is the means. Funds can come from debt, however, why debt, what means if you have no one to sell the product to.  We live in an age of greatest fear campaign. Fear is the greatest enemy of consumption. Unless we stop the fear campaign, citizens will not spend, and if citizens do not spend, entrepreneurs fail. If entrepreneurs fail, there are no jobs, no more consumers. We must immediately stop the fear campaign and allow entrepreneurs and citizens to start living a normal life.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, first of all, welcome, Commissioner. It is a pleasure to have you here, now sitting in the Commission area. I hope these months of work have been positive. The truth is that, since the start of this crisis, the Commission has shown high activism, with legislative proposals for partial reform of previous regulations — the revision of the Capital Requirements Regulation, the recent revision in relation to securitisations, prospects... — and I believe that the Socialist Group has tried to be a part of or bring together a majority in this chamber that would allow these legislative proposals to be processed with the aim of facilitating the release of capital to sustain capital. productive economy and allow the banking sector, which had been at the focus of the previous crisis, now that it is facing this crisis in principle with better capital ratios, to help. We certainly have done so, with all the proposals, and in today's debate on the proposal for a Directive for the protection of investors we have ambivalent feelings. We believe that the Commission's proposal was reasonably reasoned, but we also consider that the rapporteur of this House, Markus Ferber, has tried to expand the area of liberalisation, for review, of the Directive which the Commission itself had carried out. It has also done so a few months before the Commission itself presented the proposal for a comprehensive revision of MiFID, without the necessary technical support, without the impact reports engsing a wider debate in this house. Markus complained that we had not had the opportunity to discuss this directive in committee, and it is true. But I would also like to share that this debate would have taken longer from the European Commission, with a deeper analysis of the impact, and that some of the proposals in this report should most likely be in the future review that you are going to prepare. In any case, I believe that my group has done the work, and I would particularly like to congratulate our rapporteur, Eero Hein-luoma, because I believe that he has managed to get the debate right. And it has channeled it and allowed some of the rapporteur's proposals not to finally be in this text, which is why our group will support it, but we certainly believe that there has been no necessary public debate for the reforms to be adopted, bearing in mind that we are going to have a formal proposal for a thorough review of MiFID next year. We are therefore going to the tripartite dialogues, we hope to have this proposal approved in the coming weeks, but in the miFID review my group will be very demanding.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which For the first time, a very warm greeting from me here from Berlin to our new Financial Markets Commissioner Mairead McGuinness. I look forward to further good cooperation.  This debate here on the reform of our financial markets is indeed taking place in a very difficult situation – in a situation of serious economic upheaval in Europe, the extent of which is not yet clear. Gross domestic product has fallen by 8%. We have record-breaking aid programmes: EUR 400 billion in Germany alone; Europe will put EUR 750 billion into the works. Many other states are also indebted to stabilize the economy during this period.  At the same time, technology companies are making record profits, especially in the area of Internet services, while the real economic activities of smaller companies are suffering major losses. Inequality and economic concentration of power are increasing. Unfortunately, in this situation, we still have no progress in increasing the taxation of these global digitised activities in the market.  The ECB has acted decisively: it has so far bought EUR 600 billion in bonds, put EUR 1 500 billion in cheap liquidity into the market, and at the same time the capital requirements for the banking system have been reduced by some EUR 100 billion. In the summer alone, about 6% of bank loans were deferred, and in some Member States more than 10%. This means that we are entering a situation of severe economic upheaval, in a situation with low bank equity – still only around 5% of the balance sheet total. In summary, a new banking crisis is looming and we have to ask ourselves tough questions about the resolution of banks that are in difficulty. In this situation, we are discussing mini-reforms in the financial market that will not solve these major problems. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, let us deal with these major issues, rather than pursuing symbolic politics, which ultimately amounts to individual deregulations that cannot solve the major economic problems – which we must address.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, i also have a special greeting at this first meeting in plenary and my sincere wishes for good work and good success in your duties.  As our coordinator Jonás Fernández has already said, my group has neither made efforts nor willingness to solve concrete problems of financing the economy, to put better capital conditions so that banks can continue to support the economy, to put more resources from European funds at the disposal of The Member States so that the economy and employment could be defended and that the pandemic could be addressed from the outset.  We have therefore been part of all the urgent reforms that made sense and we will also support this initiative, but because it was possible at this stage to moderate the intentions of the rapporteur Markus Ferber, who wanted to take the opportunity to move forward on the path of deregulation, on the pretext of urgent changes in the context of the financial crisis, and so we are not going.   We expect a structural change to the financial markets directive proposed by the European Commission, with an impact assessment properly presented, and the responsibility of the European Commission, and that is what we lack and that is what we lack in this process.  It cannot be all on the pretext of the crisis and deregulation changes cannot be made on the pretext of responding to the crisis. That will not accept, and so we will be here to continue working, to find the best conditions for financing the European economy, defending employment and promoting european employment, but it is not worth everything. It is certainly not worth using the pretext of the crisis to advance structural reforms or reverse the right reforms made in the past of consumer protection and protection of European investors.

name: Aurore LALUCQ
text: Madam President, yet another quick fix, yet another contingency plan and, in fact, not a week ago without us having to decide on one of these famous contingency plans. We would like it to be on social issues, on economic issues, but not every time it is about banking and financial issues. So sincerely what is the urgency today of reviving securitisation, what is the urgency today of easing prudential rules or transparency issues? None and in truth, we all know, today we have a front of the banking lobby, which works hand in hand with some states that come to deregulate, to unravel everything that can be with this new element of language. If the banks were at the origin of the 2008 crisis, they are now the solution to the crisis. Honestly, how would our economy suffer from safer banking regulation? I don't think so. It is time to protect Europeans more than banks, it is also time sincerely to start dealing with the real issues, that is, the issue of climate change and to see how we adapt the micro and macro prudential rules to an event, that of climate change, which will be much worse than the COVID crisis.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Madam President, the approach to this proposal is deeply flawed. As part of the recovery package, the aim is to facilitate more private investment to counter the problems faced by firms as a result of COVID-19. Regulatory requirements that administratively clutter the mobilisation of such investment will be eased while the effects of the pandemic last. Yet more generally, the intention is to make the basic regulatory text less burdensome on investors and financial intermediaries, but mainly the latter.  The target is to dust away so-called formal burdens. The recovery package is serving as a basis from which longer-term changes to the regulatory framework are carried out. Yet, a comprehensive review of the framework is scheduled for the near future. But why pre-empt it as of now without a proper assessment? At a time of crisis, investor confidence can act fast. To maintain existing levels of investment globalisation, let alone increase them as we are seeking to do, is a stiff challenge. If we decrease consumer protection or appear to be doing so for a longer-term rationale than the one defined by the COVID crisis, the whole exercise loses coherence, and that’s a bad idea.

name: Marion WALSMANN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In four weeks, Christmas is, and so many people are thinking about how to surprise their loved ones: Alexa for the grandma or smartwatch for the daughter. Whether it's Christmas gifts or other commercial products, everyone wants to trust the products they're buying. In our internal market, we must ensure that consumers are protected from dangerous products, even if they involve new technologies such as artificial intelligence.  That is why it is important to create legal clarity. We will succeed in this by identifying and closing the corresponding legal loopholes, for example in the general product safety directive, for AI products in particular, without undermining the sector-specific regulations. We should stick to the risk-based approach, which means that the higher the risk of the product with AI use, the stricter conditions should apply to admission to the internal market. (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Excuse me, Ms Walsmann, I have made a mistake. We should have finished the previous debate, which means that I should of course have given the floor first to Commissioner McGuinness and then we change to your topic. You speak and then again the Commissioner.  Ms McGuinness, welcome to Parliament in your new role!  So, we finish the first debate.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I know from being in the chair that it’s difficult sometimes to keep watching everything, and I look forward to our next item. But look, I want to be very clear to colleagues who are suspicious about what we are doing in the Commission, and maybe it’s good that this item is first up on my agenda. I am no supporter of light-touch regulation, and I’m going to repeat that for all ears: I do not support light-touch regulation. The second observation is that our banks are stronger going into this crisis because of regulation, and therefore we have had the flexibility so banks can lend. So be very clear: this is not an agenda for deregulation, and I hope that you hear my words and take them as they are. Indeed, nor are they an agenda for over-bureaucratic systems, and I think what we have to do, as the Commission and the co-legislators, is work together effectively so that our regulation works and that it has an impact. The reason why we went for a quick fix is because we needed to react to the COVID-19 crisis. Indeed, some of you have rightly used this evening’s debate to talk about some of the challenges that we will face in the coming months, and they will be very difficult, and you know that before the end of this year the Commission will come forward with a communication on non-performing loans. And we do that so that we raise this issue which will face us in the coming months. We don’t know when, but we want to prepare. So do not look on the Commission as an ally for bureaucracy or for light-touch regulation. I lived through light-touch regulation and I know it does not work. So I hope that you are convinced, those of you who had concerns about what we are doing, that this is an agenda for something that none of us wish or want, and I need to be very clear on that, and I hope that message gets through. There were some other specific issues raised about why are we not dealing with the social-economic, why are we only dealing with these sorts of financial issues. But clearly there is a link between public health and the economy, and banks, and financial stability. You cannot separate one from the other, and I think we all know that and we need to work together on it. And particularly when you mentioned the climate crisis, as one of the colleagues did: this is integral to what we’re trying to do. Publicly, I have said very loudly that we will not allow Covid to take our eye off the issue of addressing climate change. The challenge is greater for us, and therefore I think the challenge for our institutions is to work very effectively, so that even with the COVID-19 public health crisis, which we are not out of yet, we will legislate effectively and deal with the climate emergency, the biodiversity challenge, the environmental difficulties. We’re also looking at the social aspects of companies, not just the financial. So I want you to be very clear today, in my first appearance in Parliament, that there will be no light-touch regulation on my watch – but there will, I hope, be effective regulation that you, as Members of this Parliament, have helped to shape. I want to thank the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) for the work that they’ve done and Marcus Ferber for the work that he has done as rapporteur. The differences that are, if you like, on the floor this evening can be resolved if we listen to each other very carefully. Remember that I come from a background of the food supply chain, of agricultural markets. I fought for unfair trading practices legislation, against the wishes of some in the House, but we got there. So please rest assured: we are in very serious times here. What we are trying to do, and we hope we will be effective, is to make sure that finance flows to SMEs, that those sectors which are currently very hit by this pandemic, who have had to open and close because of the various waves of this pandemic, will survive. And I think we are concerned that some sectors may not survive, or they will be much changed. So let me again stress why we are doing this: it is to try and ease capital flows. It is nothing else. We know that there will be a bigger review of MIFID at some time, and I value the points that have been made here, and I hope we can work together on that review and do the best for both investors and those companies who need the investment. In my first appearance here, I think it was good to clear the air on where I stand. I hope you also heard very clearly what I intend to do. But I would ask you – and I think this will be the case: this is a different time for us all. None of us have ever lived or worked through a public health pandemic, which we are not yet clear of – the end, if you like. We hope that in 2021, vaccination will help and that, as some said, we will get back to normal. However, I don’t think we will get back to the past, and there were aspects of our normal past that we should perhaps not go back to. So let us use what we have learned from this crisis, and indeed will continue to learn, to regulate better and effectively, and I promise you that that is my intention as the Commissioner with this responsibility. I wish I didn’t have it on my shoulders, because it will be a heavy responsibility. But if you put your shoulder with mine (socially distanced, of course), I think we can do good things, and I think we will all be proud eventually of the changes that we make. I ask you to support this report.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – The next item is the brief presentation of marion Walsmann's report on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on product safety in the internal market [2019/2190(INI)] (A9-0207/2020). Mr Rapporteur, since I had to interrupt you without you making any mistake, I had made that mistake, and perhaps you can make that introductory speech again.  You now have four minutes. Here you go, Mrs. Walsmann.

name: Marion WALSMANN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In four weeks, Christmas is, and so many people are thinking about how to surprise their loved ones: Alexa for the grandma or smartwatch for the daughter. Whether it's Christmas gifts or other commercial products, everyone wants to trust the products they're buying. In our European internal market, we must ensure that consumers are protected from dangerous products, even if they involve new technologies such as artificial intelligence. That is why it is important to create legal clarity. We will succeed in this by identifying and closing the corresponding legal loopholes, for example in the general product safety directive, for AI products in particular, without undermining the sector-specific regulations. We should stick to the risk-based approach, which means that the higher the risk of the product with AI use, the stricter conditions should apply to admission to the internal market. We should also avoid administrative burdens and review the impact of the measures on SMEs. Over the years, the number of dangerous products has increased progressively: 29% of the most frequently reported products were toys, and 50% of all products classified as hazardous last year came from the People's Republic of China. Market surveillance authorities must therefore cooperate even more specifically and across borders with customs authorities and also with online marketplaces. They need to be better equipped to identify unsafe products, even using innovative technologies. The European database for dangerous products, RAPEX, needs to be modernised and made more user-friendly and better known. Recalls must also be made in such a way that they actually reach those who have bought the products, which unfortunately is not the case today. Especially in the Corona era, consumers in some Member States are completely reliant on online purchases. Online marketplaces could make a significant contribution to ensuring that dangerous products are not offered to consumers in the first place, that they are immediately withdrawn from the market and that the buyers of these products are informed. The measures proposed in the report aim to increase the safety of all products, whether they are purchased online or offline, whether or not there are sector-specific rules for these products, and whether they have been purchased by a supplier inside or outside the EU.  We have formulated this objective together, and I would therefore like to express my sincere thanks to the shadow rapporteurs and their teams for their excellent cooperation. Even though the negotiations were not easy and were difficult due to Corona restrictions, we nevertheless managed to reach unanimous agreement on a text in the Committee on the Internal Market. If we stick together as a team in plenary, the Commission will get a strong signal from the European Parliament that we are speaking with one voice when it comes to strengthening product safety and thus consumer protection and the European internal market. That would be the best Christmas present for our European consumers.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I should like to thank Ms Walsmann very much. I’m delighted you mentioned Christmas, because a lot of us have fears around Christmas, but it’s nice to look on it as an opportunity, and of course when we’re buying gifts to think of safety. So thank you for your good work on this. It’s both important and timely.  Buying a safe product is the utmost important thing – it protects consumers and also the functioning of the single market, and all products sold on the market should be safe, but you have raised a number of very important issues when it comes to non-food products. Most of these issues correspond with the main objectives of the revision of the General Product Safety Directive, which is planned for the second quarter of next year. And this includes the safety of consumer products, linked, as you said, to new technologies, like connected products or products powered by artificial intelligence and the need to address the growth in online sales. These issues need to be tackled from different angles and we’ll carry out the revision of the General Product Safety Directive in conjunction with other initiatives such as the Digital Services Act, the revision of the Machinery Directive and initiatives on artificial intelligence. The Commission is also working on delegated acts under the Radio Equipment Directive.  In your report, you underline the importance of the recently adopted regulation on market surveillance and compliance. This new regulation is a major step forward for the 70 pieces of harmonised product legislation, many of them on product safety, such as the Low Voltage Directive and the Toy Safety Directive. It will provide better protection for consumers, it will greatly help national inspectors, and the implementation of this regulation is ongoing.  The Commission will also support the EU Product Compliance Network, providing funding from the single market programme, and we thank Parliament for emphasising the importance of market surveillance in this programme.  This report also calls on the Commission to encourage more online marketplaces to join the Product Safety Pledge. Just two weeks ago, two new online marketplaces joined the pledge, which brings the total number of signatories to nine major online actors.  The report also raises issues linked to ineffective recalls of dangerous products from consumers, and I think this is an area of deep concern. Most consumers are not sometimes even aware that they own a recalled product and many others continue to use dangerous products despite seeing a recall notice. I think that is deeply concerning but important to stress.  We are currently working on developing guidance on product recalls and we will also look at this issue during the revision of the General Product Safety Directive. So thank you for this opportunity this evening, for your work and I look forward to tomorrow’s vote.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The processing of the item is closed. The amendments will be put to the vote tomorrow, 24 March. The final vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 November 2020. Adopted on 15 November 2020. The same applies to the previous Ferber report on the markets for financial instruments. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: In writing. I am very pleased with this debate today. Indeed, the development of the European product safety system is a demonstration of the essential role that the European Union plays: protecting our fellow citizens, our consumers from the dangers of the modern world. At the same time, all the rules established by the Union are also a demonstration of our capacity for beneficial influence: products that meet European Union standards are also found in third-country markets.  However, the stakes remain high. They may be new as the development of new chemicals, the increasingly important place of digital, software and artificial intelligence. They can be linked to crime as the danger of counterfeit products not meeting the standards. Or they may be linked to the division and increasing diversification of supply chains.  Finally, it is essential to strengthen EU border controls on imported products, especially from China, which is still the country of origin for more than half of the products reported in the European RAPEX system.

name: Andżelika Anna MOŻDŻANOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " Technology development is faster than law-making. The General Product Safety Directive has not changed in 20 years. It's economic absurd! We must immediately adapt the rules to the economy of the digital age.  Online product acquisition is standard in the 21st century, further highlighted by the Covid-19 pandemic. Many everyday products are equipped with AI and IoT technologies. Smart home devices, connected to a single platform and controlled via the Internet, give us the ability to control, e.g. in terms of electricity consumption, and this has a positive impact on ecological sustainability.  On the other hand, putting all information online creates many risks, so let us use modern platforms, save energy, but also protect consumers while maintaining their safety and the competitiveness of businesses. Let us remember that cyberspace is not just the EU, and products and new technologies offered by external countries often do not have sufficient safeguards to protect consumers' rights and data. It is therefore important that the revision of the directive takes into account not only the single market, but also how to deal with unfair competition from outside the EU.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – The next item is a brief presentation of magdalena Adamowicz's report by Magdalena Adamowicz, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on strengthening media freedom: protecting journalists in Europe, hate speech, disinformation and the role of platforms [2020/2009(INI)] (A9-0205/2020).

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I am pleased and congratulate you on your choice.  We believed that the European Union would protect democracy. This is not the case. We believed that our law and the memory of millions of victims of wars would protect us from authoritarianism and nationalism. This is not the case. We believed that democracy was immune to anti-democratic manipulation. This is not the case.  It is rare that strong words about mortal danger are heard, because they are rarely true. Today they are like never before. Today we are witnessing the annulment of democracy. A vote cast out of hatred, on the basis of misinformation or lack of information, even the real one counted, will never be a democratic choice. It is, at most, a formal caricature of it. Today, through lies and hatred, power is gained or maintained in many places around the world, including in the European Union. That is why, here and now, as far as possible, our common voice, the voice of Europeans, the voice of the children of generations dying for freedom, the voice of parents who want peace and prosperity for future generations must sound.  The media is meant to serve the truth, not the lie. The media is intended to serve the select, not the select. The media is meant to control power, not to maintain it. That is why the media must be independent, and when they are attacked and destroyed, we must defend free media. The media is supposed to defend democracy, but the media can also kill democracy. The media can also kill a man. It is their independence that determines which of these roles the media performs. Therefore, anyone who treats the rules of democracy as an obstacle, not a safeguard against abuses of power, every autocrat at all costs the independent media will destroy.  That is why we Europeans must have media independence and pluralism on the banner. There is no freedom without media independence, there is no democracy without media pluralism. Excessive concentration, dependence on state money bought by oligarchy or state corporations is an alarm that media funding is becoming an electoral tool, a tool of crimes against democracy.  Therefore, for independent journalism, especially local and investigative journalism, there must be a permanent place in the multiannual financial framework. I therefore ask for the establishment of a permanent European fund for direct financial support for independent journalists and the media. There must be no shortage of money to defend our democracy when there is a lot of money to destroy it. We must protect independent journalists. They face violence and intimidation, they are murdered here in the European Union. Women journalists are disproportionately more likely to encounter hatred and intimidation. Finally, it is time to put an end to the silence of women's voices. The protection of independent journalists must have a legal dimension, which is why I call on the Commission to present a legislative act that will establish minimum standards throughout the European Union for strategic actions, the so-called SLAPP. To conclude, I will say as clearly as possible: if we do not defend freedom of the media, the European Union and our democracy will collapse. And it doesn't matter which becomes the first. Anyone, regardless of political colour, who is not afraid of the controlling role of the media, anyone who believes in the power of argument and not the power of manipulation, anyone who does not want a return to the dark times of nationalism and authoritarianism, anyone who believes in freedom, I ask you to support my report. Let us protect the free European media, let us protect our democracy!

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank the rapporteur for her very strong words and very powerful presentation this evening, and indeed for her work on this report. Let me be very clear that media freedom and pluralism are enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. And I agree that democracy cannot work without a free and independent media. It’s more important than ever that journalists are able to do their job so that citizens have access to accurate information. So I really do appreciate this work and perhaps, as a former journalist, I appreciate the depth of your comments this evening.  The Commission as you know is currently finalising a series of initiatives that will address many of the issues in this report. The safety of journalists is a top priority that we do intend to address. We have already announced an initiative against abusive litigation targeting journalists and rights defenders in our 2021 work programme, and this will be part of the European Democracy Action Plan which the Commission will present on 2 December. As part of the first annual rule of law report, we analysed the framework for the protection of journalists in all Member States, alongside the independence of audio-visual regulatory authorities, transparency of media ownership, the political independence of media, and state advertising in the media sector.  The conclusion is that no Member State is immune from the risks to media freedom and pluralism. This is also clear from the media pluralism monitor co-funded by the EU, with the support of the European Parliament.  We welcome the report’s emphasis on the importance of media pluralism, media freedom and media literacy to fight disinformation. The code of practice on disinformation for online platforms and the advertising sector is a good example of structured cooperation to ensure greater transparency and accountability. It’s also a useful framework to monitor and improve platforms’ policies on disinformation. The European Democracy Action Plan will outline the next steps to upgrade this code.  This report also highlights the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on the media, especially local media, with estimated reduction in revenues of as much as 80%. To help the sector recover and support its digital transformation the Commission will also present a media and audio-visual action plan on 2 December. We will also propose the Digital Service Act by the end of the year. This aims to harmonise a clear set of due-diligence obligations for online platforms, including notice and action procedures and voluntary proactive measures for illegal content such as illegal hate speech, redress mechanisms, accountability measures and obligations to cooperate with public authorities. One of the main objectives of this instrument will be to improve the safety of users online across the European Union, while improving the protection of their fundamental rights.  The Digital Service Act will be adopted along with the Digital Markets Act, which aims to better address market deficiencies resulting from the position of large online platforms. The Commission will continue working with the European Parliament to strengthen media freedom and pluralism, as well as to fight hate speech and disinformation, while protecting fundamental rights. This is essential for our democracy and the rule of law. I thank you for this report.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The processing of the item is closed. The amendments will be put to the vote tomorrow, 24 March. The final vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 November 2020. Adopted on 15 November 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – This topic is of great importance to me; as both a citizens’ and a former career journalist, I am fully aware of the fundamental importance of media freedom and pluralism for our democracies. It is never too much to remind this to our young generations, as their future depends on it. Professional independent journalism requires very hard work facing daily difficulties of all sorts from lack of resources to intimidations or pressures, and the Covid crisis added more hardships and even abuses from local authorities during the Covid-19 crisis. This resolution recognises the irreplaceable role of professional journalists and stresses that it is essential to ensure and maintain their independence from political interference, no matter the times – or the crisis – we live in. The resolution reminds the sacrifices of journalists such as murders of Daphne Caruana Galizia in Malta and Ján Kuciak and his fiancée Martina Kušnírová in Slovakia due to their investigative work to unveil corruption and other crimes. Calling our Member States to protect a vibrant, independent, pluralist and free media sector is of crucial importance and it is something we should all cherish and fight for. I want to highlight the fundamental role of investigative journalism in acting as a watchdog in a democratic society.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The COVID-19 pandemic has shown us the importance of access to reliable and fact-based information. In a situation where disinformation and media manipulation can cost lives, access to proven information provided by independent media is crucial.  Free media and pluralism are also one of the pillars of a democratic system that plays an important role in social surveillance and raises citizens' awareness. Unfortunately, even within the Borders of the Union, there are known cases of pressure on journalists, as well as attacks or attacks. The killings of Daphne Caruana Galizii in Malta and Ján Kuciak and his fiancée Martina Kušnírová in Slovakia are significant because of their journalistic investigations. Therefore, the EU and individual Member States must work for the freedom and independence of the media. Attempts to silence critical and independent media or to use public media for political gain, for example, by excluding the opposition from public debate are unacceptable.  Common standards and indicators on media independence at Union level, as well as the collection of information and statistics on media freedom and pluralism, can help us ensure that Europeans have access to the highest quality information, free from manipulation or propaganda. It is also important that Member States respond to all forms of attacks on journalists and make efforts to ensure impartial and effective investigations into these matters.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Hate speech and disinformation are increasingly emerging as tools to increase social polarisation, which is used for political purposes. Combating these phenomena is important for respect for fundamental rights, but also essential for maintaining independence, the rule of law and democracy.  On the one hand, real cases of hate speech must be strongly opposed, and on the other hand, it must not be allowed to be a tool for restricting freedom of expression or to paralyse the fundamental power of human judgement.  The question has to be asked: is censorship the only way to have theoretical hate speech? The road is dangerous, because it can be used to close people's mouths simply because they do not think as they should, that they have different views. Already today we see manifestations of ideologization of this concept and use it as a whip on political opponents. And the future may turn out to be as Seen by George Orwell, who wrote, "The further society drifts from the truth, the more it hates those who preach it. Truth is a new hate speech. Telling the truth in times of collapse is a revolutionary act."  Therefore, building society's resilience to false narratives through education and teaching critical thinking is essential in the fight against hate speech.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the report by Carlo Calenda, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the new European Industrial Strategy [2020/2076(INI)] (A9-0197/2020).

name: Carlo CALENDA
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we began to write this report on the days when we were overwhelmed by the first pandemic of the modern era. An event that determines, in addition to the dramatic health consequences, a symmetrical shock on supply and demand that has been unprecedented since the Second World War. The effort made during these months has always had as its objective a shared result, aimed at strengthening Parliament's role, even pending the review of the industrial policy strategy announced by the Commission. For this work I would like to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs. The 700 amendments received have become 17 compromise amendments, balanced and widely supported. Our report divides industrial strategy into two distinct phases: a first phase aimed at the recovery of the production system after the emergency and a second phase that aims to build an industrial system that is socially, economically and environmentally resilient. At its heart is the need to promote and accelerate the dual digital and environmental transition. The goal of climate neutrality in 2050 remains our compass. The report also takes account of the external dimension of industrial policy. In a world that has become less open and harsher, the European Union, while remaining committed to free and balanced trade, both bilaterally and multilaterally, must make more assertive use of trade defence instruments, activate measures that push towards reciprocity in public procurement and monitor the acquisition of strategic companies by State-owned enterprises and companies linked to foreign governments. The report is based on a number of key points. I will mention a few of them. Firstly, a strong focus on social aspects, in particular training, in order to avoid job losses and safeguard territorial cohesion in the spirit of the 'No one left behind' principle. We know from experience over the last thirty years that transformations, if not properly managed, lead to deep rifts between winners and losers. Among the latter, young people and women are the most affected groups. Secondly, a balanced review of the rules on competition and state aid in order to protect our strategic autonomy and global competitiveness and to enable support for investment in the environment and digitalisation, preserving and completing the single market. Thirdly, ad hoc measures to enable SMEs to participate on an equal footing with large companies in the dual transition, measures that must be easy and immediate to use, such as tax credits to encourage investment and training co-financed by European funds. Fourthly, proposals for an EU Next Generation that is a real driving force for investment by encouraging EIB guarantees and capital increases. Fifthly, proposals to provide companies with the appropriate tools to make an effective contribution to reducing CO2 emissions in line with climate law. In this respect, we must at all costs prevent environmental processing that is not adequately supported financially and protected from environmental dumping, including through the imposition of a Carbon Border Tax, from causing relocations to countries with less stringent emission standards, with a consequent increase in pollution and job losses here. The Commission's analysis of ecosystems will be key to selecting interventions and priorities. In the report we have also called for a system of Key Performance Indicators and impact analyses, which will help to verify ex ante and ex post the effectiveness of the measures taken and the instruments put in place. The European Union urgently needs to have an appropriate, operational, well-funded and properly coordinated industrial strategy. This report is an important opportunity for Parliament to speak with a strong and unique voice. We have worked with great care and passion on the text, precisely in view of this goal!

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Calenda for his work and for his words this evening. Europe has always been the home of industry and, throughout history, industry has proven its ability to lead change. To prepare for the future, Europe needs industry that is greener, more digital and more resilient, while remaining competitive on the global stage. EU institutions, Member States and regions have to work alongside industry to make this happen. We must do more than just adapt. We want to accelerate and enable change and innovation. This is why we must move forward on our agenda, as announced in the new industrial strategy. Important initiatives have been delivered, such as the Action Plan on Critical Raw Materials, and many are still to come. A deeper and more digital single market; a global level playing field and open markets; working towards climate neutrality and a more circular economy; fostering employment and innovation, skills and investments: all these will be essential to achieve our goals. The COVID—19 crisis has increased the momentum to use the recovery as an opportunity to accelerate our joint efforts. We will update the industrial strategy next year to take account of the lessons learned from the pandemic and to ensure that it continues to be fit for purpose to lead the green and digital transformations. To achieve this, we will have to work together. In updating our industrial strategy, we plan to work closer than ever with the Member States, as well as with industry and other stakeholders: for example, in the context of industrial ecosystems, alliances and the Industry Forum. Europe has an excellent industrial foundation. We have the benefit of diverse and competitive companies of all sizes, including SMEs and social economy enterprises, and a huge range of different industries, not only a few giants. That’s why the focus of the new industrial strategy is on industrial ecosystems, incorporating all players operating in a value chain: not just a few big companies, but value chains in which companies of all sizes can participate. Such an approach has already shown its benefits in the field of batteries. In July, the Commission launched the European Clean Hydrogen Alliance and the new European Raw Materials Alliance in September. A European alliance on industrial data and cloud is also on the way. Soon we will launch a new industrial forum, which will bring together companies of all sizes with researchers and unions and national governments. Our new industrial strategy is part of a package of initiatives to make Europe’s businesses future ready. There will also be a dedicated strategy for SMEs and concrete steps to address barriers in the way of a well-functioning single market. This single market is Europe’s strongest asset to allow all of our businesses to grow and compete in Europe and beyond. The openness of Europe’s economy is a source of prosperity and competitiveness. We need a European industrial policy based on competition, open markets, world—leading research and technologies, and a strong single market, which removes barriers and cuts red tape. But we must resist the simplistic temptations that come with protectionism or market distortions, while not being naive in the face of unfair competition, to ensure a level playing field beyond the single market. Reciprocity in public procurement is a key part of the industrial policy toolbox. We’re also working on legislative proposals to tackle the distortive effects of foreign subsidies on the single market. The COVID—19 crisis has highlighted that dependency on a single supplier for some specific critical goods could limit Europe’s ability to respond to future shocks. Europe needs to build up resilience and strengthen the open strategic autonomy of the EU economy in the long run, while remaining open to the world. This requires an evidence-based approach, where we first identify any vulnerabilities and then explore how to address them, notably by contributing to the diversification of our supply chains. The Commission supports the agreement found in the trilogue between the Council and Parliament on Europe’s next long—term budget and Next Generation EU, Europe’s new recovery instrument. Now it is important to move forward. The strength of our Union has always been that we overcome difficult situations by engaging with each other. So we are working hard to implement the final step on the MFF, while ensuring respect for the rule of law. This new powerful and modern long-term budget for the Union will allow us to turn the immediate challenges posed by the COVID—19 pandemic into long-term opportunities by not only supporting the recovery, but also by investing in our future. To make that future sustainable, inclusive and fair for all, we need to spend the money from the recovery instrument in a way that crowds in private investment and does not undermine the ability of our industries to compete by harming competition or weakening the single market. Honourable Members, the time to get it right is now. We do not get a second chance.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The processing of the item is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 October 2008. Adopted on 15 November 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Marc ANGEL
text: in writing. – The European industrial policy strategy should promote inclusive and sustainable industrialisation, where climate neutrality, sustainability, innovation and competitiveness should go together with social inclusiveness. Economic recovery following the pandemic must be sustainable, fair and socially just with focus on digital and green transitions. European industry represents more than 20% of our economy and directly employs about 35 million people. In addition, it accounts for 80% of goods exports. It is not a question that the new industrial strategy should enable companies to contribute to their climate-neutrality targets, but also should support firms, particularly small and medium enterprises in their transition to a digital and carbon-neutral economy with creating high-quality jobs and without undermining the EU’s competitiveness. As shadow rapporteur of the IMCO opinion I am glad that the final document is a balanced and future oriented. Amongst others, it is rightly tackling such issues as: maintaining our global role model for sustainability; reflecting on supply chain disruptions we experienced at the beginning of the pandemic and underlining the importance of cross-border value-chains; declaring that SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups are key players in our market; and equating social, environmental and economic criteria in public procurement frameworks.

name: Markus BUCHHEIT
text: Writing. – An industrial strategy that is digging the water off the German nuclear industry has failed to make sense and must be firmly and categorically rejected. This text makes the industry a victim and stirrup of a misunderstood environmental idea under the European Green Deal. This is reflected, among other things, in the irrational demand for an immediate cessation of the use of fossil fuels, in the characterisation of natural gas as a temporary energy source by 2050, and in the ECB's political positioning as a 'climate bank'. Destroying our industry has a system; You only forget in your so-called strategy that it is industry and SMEs that have to foot the bill for your climate fantasies.

name: Krzysztof JURGIEL
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Industry is of great importance in the European Union– it accounts for around 20% of the EU economy and employs nearly 35 million people. Therefore, its transformation – in digital and ecological form, taking into account the complexity of the processes – must be very carefully planned and adapted to the reality around us and rapidly changing.  Many elements of the new industrial strategy for Europe are needed for the EU to be a leader in modern production. Investments in Artificial Intelligence, improving the energy efficiency of buildings, network infrastructure, smart sectoral integration, sustainable mobility, alternative fuels or modern competences of workers are essential to take a step forward, but it must not be forgotten that all these activities will require a huge financial outlay, so it is edifices that are not left to the most deprived countries without adequate support.  Europe will gradually move away from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources such as hydrogen, wind and sun. However, it must not be forgotten that there are countries for which coal accounts for a significant part of the energy mix, and natural gas should therefore be strongly supported as a transitional instrument between coal and renewable energy sources, which in the medium term will help to significantly reduce the emissions of economies and allow the energy transition to be financially bearable for them.

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: in writing. – SMEs play a key role in the transition towards a digital and green European Industry. They are at the heart of to Europe’s recovery and prosperity. SMEs have the potential to invigorate the economy and stimulate competitiveness, bringing innovative solutions, incentivising the market to help to build a robust infrastructure, particularly as regards the platform economy. Established industrial firms can be supported by SMEs to adapt their business models to smart, digital and sustainable processes, enhancing resilience to external shocks. Consequently, SMEs are a core element of the EU’s industrial recovery, performing as catalysts of Europe’s dual transitions. SMEs are a key engine to drive the spirit of the European recovery and society’s welfare. As the backbone of the EU economy SMEs should be incentivised and supported, so they can be globally competitive. Furthermore, given the proliferation of tech-based businesses as a direct consequence of the COVID pandemic, bringing together work on the industrial strategy with that of the Data Strategy and SME Strategy can help ensure EU tech companies have the means at their disposal to benefit from their access to the single market, and therefore increase customer bases and business opportunities.

name: Susana SOLÍS PÉREZ
text: in writing. – At the heart of the COVID-19 crisis, Europe once again sees industry as an engine of quality change, competitiveness and employment.  Europe faces transformation towards Industry 4.0 at a time of change and must demonstrate that it is able to lead not only green and digital transitions, but also to fight for technological leadership and open strategic autonomy.  Only through a new industrial strategy, which respects the importance of SMEs, innovation centres and universities, can we build a leading European economy that is capable of strengthening supply chains, relocating value chains to Europe and increasing security of strategic raw material supply.  Only through public-private collaboration will we be able to create innovation ecosystems that are anchored in the competitive advantages of each of the European regions.  We must move towards a circular economy, we need to invest in alternative energy sources, such as hydrogen, to achieve the climate targets we have set ourselves, and we must also invest in skills and education to ensure that all Europeans are prepared to face the important change this new industrial strategy will bring.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – Transpose into the European industrial strategy the focus on the ecological pact, the fight against climate change and the digital transition focused on people is a priority that the crisis has made even more urgent.  The European Union as a multilateral power must promote a globalization with rules and, to do so, it must ensure a level of strategic autonomy that is not possible without a strong commitment to the transformation and recovery of its industrial fabric.  The report under discussion sets out clear principles for ensuring long-term growth, mobilising and attracting the necessary investment, ensuring the energy and digital transition, improving quality of life, creating more and better jobs, promoting innovation and strengthening entrepreneurship and the role of Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs). I also note the social, cohesion and convergence dimension that informs the proposals contained in the report.  Without promoting convergence in development between territories and assertively combating inequalities, the European Union will be weakened in the projection of its industrial vision as a reference for the new cycle of sustainable industrialisation on a planetary scale.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the report by Hilde Vautmans, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the foreign policy consequences of the Covid-19 pandemic [2020/2111(INI)] (A9-0204/2020).

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the COVID-19 crisis has shaken up the world profoundly, and we haven’t found the politics yet to cope with it. That’s the harsh but undeniable conclusion of my report. Instead of working more closely together to find a solution, the world’s superpowers have abused the pandemic to compete and to try to shape the world order to their own advantage.  So we urge Europe to strengthen its foreign policy presence in order to be able to defend its interests in the new geopolitical era – because it is a new political era. The COVID-19 pandemic has been a game changer. It has changed the relationship between the world’s biggest players. Look at the United States. Under the failed leadership of Trump, the United States opted to stand alone. There was no cooperation. Even worse, they sometimes denied the severity of the pandemic by spreading misleading information and undermined global institutions to deal with it. China actually did the same. The lack of transparency on the outbreak of the virus and attempts to withhold information about its magnitude made at the start of the battle against the virus was ineffective. Since then, the ‘virus diplomacy’ as I call it is seeking to fill the global political vacuum, and in the light of such disturbing trends, our response has been slow and disjointed.  We need to reduce our dependency on third countries in strategic sectors. We need better communication strategies and strong resilience in order to counter this information. That is what we need to do to play a bigger role in the world. My report is very clear. We need to get our own house in order first. We need to reclaim our place on the world stage to make sure our children will continue to live in a world of cooperation, democracy and the rule of law. We can no longer count on others for solutions. We need to be able to count on Europe by making it more decisive, more dynamic, and more resilient internationally.  Let us work together to finally get rid of the unanimity rule in foreign affairs, to be able to push back against the strongmen surrounding us, to build a real European defence union as the European pillar within NATO, to re-engage with the United States, to develop a new strategy towards China, and to urge them to fully cooperate with an independent international investigation into the origin of the virus. Colleagues, Commissioner, let us roll up our sleeves and launch the conference on the future of Europe. Let us show that we are serious about the geopolitical Commission. Thank you very much.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I should like to thank Ms Vautmans for her words this evening and for her work on this report. In this report, Ms Vautmans, you say COVID-19 is a game changer, and it is, and one that we were not prepared for, but it very much is a game changer. And you speak of a new political era, so let me just outline what the Commission is doing in this regard.  Firstly, we’re working on a joint communication on multilateralism that will reaffirm our commitment and propose a strategic approach, underlining the EU interest in promoting multilateral solutions. Respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law will remain at the very heart of our response to this pandemic. The new action plan on human rights and democracy seeks to reduce inequalities by combating poverty and social exclusion and by promoting non-discriminatory access to social services, including quality and affordable health services. Our global EU response to the pandemic, that brought together Team Europe, has now reached EUR 38.5 billion. We have sent a strong message of EU unity in times of crisis, as well as international solidarity and global leadership. The Western Balkans and eastern neighbourhood have remained our close partners throughout the pandemic. In your report, you call for united EU efforts to invest in the region. The economic and investment plan presented in October is a clear step in that direction. We are continuing the discussion on a reinforced EU partnership with southern neighbourhood countries. We will jointly identify concrete areas of cooperation with a focus on supporting resilience through reforms that directly impact the quality of life of citizens. COVID-19 is likely to impact conflict areas such as the Sahel or the Horn of Africa and least-developed countries disproportionately, we know this, increasing their vulnerability and the vulnerability of their citizens. We are stepping up the political dialogue with African partners ahead of the next EU-Africa summit. In the wake of the US presidential election on 3 November, the EU wants to enhance cooperation with the new US administration, not only to tackle COVID-19, but also to maintain and reform the rules-based order and crucial commitments, such as the Paris Agreement.  It is important to continue calling on China to participate in the review of lessons learned from the international health response and to address the consequences of the pandemic in developing countries, notably as regards debt relief.  Despite the limited resources for such great stakes, the next MFF provides a real opportunity for the European Union to pull its weight in leading by example, engaging with others and promoting a sustainable recovery, underpinned by our values and interests.  Thank you for your attention and I look forward to your vote and discussion.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The processing of the item is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 October 2008. Adopted on 15 November 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – Parliament's own-initiative report on the foreign policy consequences of the Covid19 epidemic was originally intended to put the events of the past year in the pandemic into an appropriate framework for interpretation. Instead, the content of the report is exhausted in criticizing the actions of some countries, including the United States, in relation to the epidemic. The report takes a position on issues not related to the pan-epidemic, in many cases on ideological grounds, such as migration routes. It is unacceptable that, under the pretext of the epidemic, the report calls for a transition to qualified majority voting in the field of EU foreign policy. This not only oversets its powers, but also ignores the strong opposition of many Member States and MEPs on this issue, since it is not possible to take away the right and opportunity of smaller Member States to represent their own interests in European foreign policy-making. This would further divide The Member States at a time of critical pandemic where, to the contrary, cooperation and greater consistency are needed. Thus, the report only weakens Europe's international positions, rather than strengthening them during the Covid19 epidemic.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – In addition to the health, economic and social crisis that the COVID-19 pandemic has caused around the world, it has provoked systemic tensions in global governance with wide-ranging and long-term implications for international relations. Today, COVID-19 concerns key aspects of the EU's foreign and security and defence policy, but it is also a turning point on the international stage, a multiplier of risks and a catalyst for change in the world order. Unfortunately, the lack of global leadership and a coordinated international response in the early stages of the crisis were a fundamental prerequisite for the rapid spread of the virus, which in turn provoked isolationist solutions, the rise of authoritarian nationalism and the sponsorship of state disinformation campaigns.  I therefore believe that the EU needs to work to revive the transatlantic partnership sooner to make fighting pandemics and other major international challenges, such as climate change, more effective. We need to find a new basis for cooperation with our US strategic partners in favour of multilateralism, international justice, the rule of law and human rights against nationalist and authoritarian ambitions.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the report by Tomas Tobé, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on improving the effectiveness of development cooperation and the effectiveness of aid [2019/2184(INI)] (A9-0212/2020).

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner McGuinness and colleagues, I have made the effectiveness and efficiency of aid my personal priority from the very moment I became Chair of the Committee on Development. This report I see as a wake-up call to put effectiveness again at the centre of development cooperation. The European Union is the biggest donor in the world and we have to take the lead now in making better use of aid. We owe this not only to the aid recipients but also to Europe’s taxpayers. And now, let us be clear: development aid can never be 100% effective and efficient, but we need to check that our aid provides pathways for communities and countries to become less and less dependent on aid. The long-term objective of our Union’s aid policy must be that the recipient countries of today will no longer need our aid tomorrow. But the needs today are high. The current COVID-19 pandemic is undoing years of progress, and we can see also at the same time that populations in developing countries are growing faster than gross national income and the job markets do. Hunger is on the rise and conflicts are increasing during the last years, and therefore we need to challenge the practices of the past and try also to adjust. This report makes clear and practical recommendations to the Commission and to the Member States. We want Team Europe to become an everyday reality of our work with developing countries. For this, we want to see a drastic increase in joint programming and joint implementation so that it covers all partner countries in the developing world. We also need clear rules and guidelines on how to make aid coordination among EU countries and the Commission a reality, and I will commit, therefore, to ask the Commission to bring forward proposals in this regard. Furthermore, we ask the Commission to publish, bi-annually, a development and effectiveness progress report covering planning, programming, implementation and results by EU institutions, EU Member States, as well as European local and regional authorities. I believe that local governments in the developing world tend to be more accountable and more in tune with the real problems and the real solutions. We want the European Commission also to start a real reflection on this and turn it into action, including when it comes to budget support. To conclude: the EU needs to remain the champion and the leader when it comes to upholding and applying the principles of aid-effectiveness to secure a real impact and to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. Commissioner McGuinness, we were together at the United Nations’ SDG and Climate Summit last year. We both heard their appreciation for our commitment, but also how everybody asked Europe to take the lead. I look forward now to turning the message from this report into actions, together with you and all the other relevant actors. So let me finish by saying: by being more effective we will achieve more. This report is a first step in that direction.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would first like to thank Mr Tobé, Chair of the Committee on Development (DEVE), very much for his excellent work in this area. Mr Tobé, I would also like to thank you for your great personal commitment as Chair of the Committee on Development.
