You mentioned the Sustainable Development Goals - and we only have a decade to deliver on them - and facing a resource gap that will grow with the impact of the Covid—19 pandemic. So we need to be more determined than ever to ensure that development is effective, and that we have development effectiveness. This is about delivering more and delivering better.  The Commission is, and has been, a leader on development effectiveness. The Team Europe approach is a clear demonstration of how the European Union and Member States could act as one in partner countries and ensure that European cooperation is delivered consistently and coherently, with a greater impact and in line with our fundamental principles.  That is why we actively promote and pursue joint programming and joint implementation and will do so increasingly, as suggested in your report, notably by identifying Team Europe initiatives. The proposed Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument will strengthen our ability to provide coherent and policy—driven cooperation. It streamlines a number of existing external financing instruments into one broad instrument. This simplification reduces the gaps or overlaps between instruments, while at the same time facilitating EU engagement with partners in a more comprehensive way. We also need to influence the behaviour of development partners beyond the EU - donors, international organisations and partner countries - and build partnerships on this issue. Team Europe will be important here as well. By speaking with a single European voice in international fora and in the governance structures of the UN, international financial institutions and other bodies, we will become more influential in promoting effectiveness among multilateralals.  Finally, the Commission remains determined to improve the transparency and accountability of our external action. Commissioner Urpilainen has been very clear about this commitment from the very start of this new Commission. Having clear and agreed targets on which to report is crucial if we wish to contribute to a better world. It is also essential for continued public support for our endeavours. The role of the European Parliament in this process is crucial.  Madam President, dear Tomas, thank you again for the recommendations of this report. I know that the Parliament will work with the Commission to improve effectiveness in the area of development. This is key.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The processing of the item is closed. The amendments will be put to the vote tomorrow, Tuesday, 24 March. The final vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 November 2020. Adopted on 15 November 2020.  Written declarations (Article 171)

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. – It is now a cliché that, together with the EU Member States, it is the world's largest donor of development. In 2019, the EU and its Member States spent EUR 75.2 billion on development cooperation, or 55.2% of the world's aid to this end. Unfortunately, this huge amount often does not reach communities in really need and the efficiency of its use is far below what can be expected. In the economic crisis caused by the coronavirus, it is even more important that we can use the resources available directly in the most efficient way possible. It is a sinful omission that, while people in need are waiting in vain for the Union's help in their homeland, the European Commission has still not allowed local churches and religiously based organisations to participate in EU development and humanitarian aid in the spirit of extreme impartiality. This omission is also highlighted in the report initiated by the People's Party, which calls on the Commission to take account of reliable ecclesiastical organisations and to involve them in the implementation of EU development projects. We must realen that churches in Africa and the Middle East are the social network through which we can most effectively help those in need locally, to create humane living conditions and to contribute to the sustainable development of their own communities.

name: Janina OCHOJSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union is the largest donor in the world, but our contribution to combating poverty and achieving the Sustainable Development Goals can be even greater if we improve the effectiveness and effectiveness of the assistance provided.  The overarching objective of development aid is to make a real change in the quality of life in a given community. The provision of resources which, if not even going directly to those in need, are intended to have an impact on the lives of the poorest.  The COVID-19 pandemic led to the withdrawal of progress in the implementation of the SDG. The phenomenon of hunger with a growing population and economic stagnation is becoming more common and the effects of climate change are affecting the most vulnerable. From 2030, 30 million young Africans are expected to enter the labour market every year. These challenges require an urgent response, but they do not need to be subject to new measures if we implement mechanisms for effective assistance, the fight against corruption and coordination, and the coherence of development efforts.  The Tobé report that we have adopted contains a list of practical recommendations to the Commission and the Member States that will make aid measures effective. I regret that the reference to the harmfulness of tying development aid has been removed from the draft report. I believe that the introduction of conditionality in development aid in the area of migration and border control is contrary to the key principles of development effectiveness.
